title: A-1 Bail Bonding Company v. Larue
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Ex Parte: A-1 Bail Bonding Company (Surety), Appellant,
        In Re: State of South Carolina, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Fredrick Larue, Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-604
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 1, 2005


  AFFIRMED
  



  
    
      
        Andrew F. Litvin, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, and Assistant Solicitor Anderson M. Horne, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This is an estreatment case.Â  A-1 Bail Bonding Company appeals the order of the trial court finding defendant Frederick Larue violated the terms of his bond and ordering $30,000 of the bond be estreated to the State.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On October 2, 2003, A-1 Bail Bonding signed an appearance bond in the amount of $50,000 for Defendant Fredrick Larue.Â  The appearance bond required him to appear â€œwhen notified.â€ Â In 2004, Larueâ€™s counsel made a motion to be relieved as counsel, and Larue was ordered to appear before the circuit court.Â  Upon his failure to appear for that hearing in May of 2004, the trial court issued a bench warrant for his arrest.Â  At the first estreatment hearing on October 8, 2004, the trial court gave A-1 ten additional days to secure documentation that Larue was incarcerated in another state.Â  On October 29, 2004, A-1 provided the trial court with information of Larueâ€™s ongoing incarceration at the Joseph Hart Correctional Institute in Oklahoma, but did not produce Larue or secure his release from this institution.Â  Because Larue â€œfail[ed] to appear in the Court of General Sessions when duly summoned or did not comply with the provisions of good behavior as required by the bond,â€ the trial court ordered estreatment of the bond in the amount of $30,000 to be payable within 15 days of the date of the order.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Where the terms of a statute are clear and unambiguous, there is no room for construction, and the court must apply such terms according to their literal meaning.Â  Gentry v. Yonce, 337 S.C. 1, 13, 522 S.E.2d 137, 143 (1999).Â  An appellate court cannot construe a statute without regard to its plain meaning.Â  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002). Â Neither may it resort to a forced interpretation in an attempt to expand or limit the scope of a statute.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS

A-1 claims the trial court erred in ordering forfeiture of the bond for the suretyâ€™s failure to secure Larueâ€™s presence at a hearing on the motion to be relieved as counsel.Â  We disagree.
The overriding purpose of requiring a criminal defendant to post bond before his release from custody is to insure his appearance at trial.Â  State v. Workman, 274 S.C. 341, 343, 263 S.E.2d 865, 866 (1980).Â  As guarantor, the surety on an appearance bond undertakes the risk of forfeiture in the event the defendant does not appear for trial.Â  Pride v. Anders, 266 S.C. 338, 341, 223 S.E.2d 184, 186 (1976).Â  Thus, the possible forfeiture of bond is incentive for sureties to ensure the appearance of the defendant.Â  The issue of whether a bond forfeiture should be remitted, and if so, to what extent, is vested in the discretion of the trial judge.Â  Workman, 274 S.C. at 343, 263 S.E.2d at 866.
Section 38-53-70 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) provides: 

  If a defendant fails to appear at a court proceeding to which he has been summoned, the court must issue a bench warrant for the defendant.Â  If the surety fails to surrender the defendant or place a hold on the defendantâ€™s release from incarceration . . . within thirty days of the issuance of the bench warrant, the bond shall be forfeited.

(emphasis added).Â  In addition, section 17-15-20 of the South Carolina Code (2003) states that an appearance bond carries certain conditions, including the defendantâ€™s appearance in court and his good behavior.Â  Estreatment for a violation of the good behavior condition is proper.Â  State v. Boatwright, 310 S.C. 281, 283, 423 S.E.2d 139, 140 (1992).Â  
It is clear the hearing on counselâ€™s motion to be relieved was an integral part of the trial proceedings.Â  Therefore, Larueâ€™s presence at that court proceeding was vital and ordered by the court.Â  Furthermore, he did not notify the court of his whereabouts, as required by the contract.Â  Most importantly, Larue pled guilty to a crime in Oklahoma and was sentenced to 12 years imprisonment.Â  Therefore, it is beyond dispute that he breached the condition of good behavior.Â Â  
Unquestionably, Larueâ€™s bond was legally forfeited, and the trial court properly entered judgment on the bond.Â  However, A-1 also claims the trial court abused its discretion in estreating the bond in the amount of $30,000.Â  We disagree.
Section 38-53-70 of the South Carolina Code requires the trial court to consider the costs to the State â€œresulting from the necessity to continue or terminate the defendantâ€™s trial and the efforts of law enforcement or agencies to locate the defendant.â€Â  The trial court should also consider the purpose of the bond and the nature and willfulness of the default.Â  Boatwright, 310 S.C. at 287, 423 S.E.2d at 142-43.Â  We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in estreating the bond in the amount of $30,000.Â  The State presented sufficient evidence of substantial costs to the State, and the purpose of the bond was to ensure the defendantâ€™s presence in court proceedings involving him.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â

title: Aiken Technical College v. Two State Construction Co., Inc.
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Aiken Technical College, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Two State Construction Co., Inc., LS3P Associates, LTD., Buford Goff Company, Columbia Sheet Metal, Inc., Johnson Controls, Inc., and John Doe,
           Respondents.
      
    
  



  
    Appeal From Aiken County
      Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge
  


Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-605
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 1, 2005Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James D. Nance and T. Paul Timmerman, of Aiken, for Appellant.
        Franklin J. Smith, Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., Rebecca Lafitte, Robert E. Horner, Richard H. Willis, Thomas M. Kennaday and Robert C. Brown, all of Columbia, N. Keith Emge and M. Elizabeth Jowers, both of Charleston Robin A. Braithwaite, of Aiken, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Aiken Technical College appeals the trial courtâ€™s order of dismissal in regards to its negligence cause of action against Two State Construction Company, Inc., LS3P Associates, Ltd., Buford Goff & Associates, Inc., The Trane Company, Columbia Sheet Metal, Inc., and Johnson Controls, Inc. for an HVAC systemâ€™s failure that allegedly caused significant damage.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1997, Aiken Technical College entered into an Architect Agreement with LS3P Associates, Ltd. for the design of a new Information Technology Training Center at the college.Â  LS3P then entered into an Owner Consultant Agreement with Buford Goff & Associates, Inc. to perform the mechanical, electrical, and plumbing services on the project.Â  The college also entered into a contract with Two State Construction Company, Inc. for the actual construction of the Center, which included the installation of three HVAC units by Columbia Sheet Metal, Inc.Â  The Trane Company manufactured and sold the HVAC units and their operating computers.Â  Johnson Controls, Inc. installed and maintained the operating computers.Â  
In December 2000, the HVAC units at the Center failed to operate properly, releasing water into the Center, which caused substantial damage to the Center and its contents.Â  Upon being notified of the incident, Buford Goff, LS3P, Johnson Controls, and Two State Construction joined the college in assessing the damage at the Center.Â  Applied Science and Engineering, on behalf of the college, also examined the building and issued a report outlining the possible causes of the incident.Â  
On November 26, 2003, the college filed this action against Two State Construction, LS3P, Buford Goff, The Trane Company, Columbia Sheet Metal, Johnson Controls (collectively Respondents), and an unknown party for negligence, breach of contract, breach of implied warranties of merchantability, fitness, and workmanlike manner, and breach of express warranties.Â  The college alleged actual and punitive damages as a result of the HVAC unitâ€™s failure.Â  Respondents filed a joint motion to dismiss the collegeâ€™s claims under Rule 12(b)(6) and Rule 56, SCRCP, on the grounds that the collegeâ€™s complaint failed to set forth facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action because the Consolidated Procurement Code, section 11-35-4230 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003), is the exclusive means for resolving contract controversies between a state agency, such as the college, and Respondents.Â  Respondents also asserted the collegeâ€™s claims should be dismissed because the Procurement Code provides a one year time limitation.Â  
At the hearing, the college conceded the Procurement Code was the exclusive means for resolving all the contract causes of action.Â  However, it argued the claims for negligence were not covered by the Procurement Code.Â  The trial court found the contracts between the college and Respondents were governed by the terms of the Procurement Code, providing the exclusive means and exclusive original jurisdiction of all disputes with the chief procurement officer and the Procurement Review Panel.Â  Moreover, the trial court held that â€œnothing in the statute or case law supports [the collegeâ€™s] contentionâ€ that the exclusivity provision of the Procurement Code does not apply to tort actions and granted Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss, or in the alternative, for summary judgment.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
As permitted by Rule 56(c) and (e), SCRCP, the trial court treated Respondentsâ€™ Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, motion as a motion for summary judgment because the trial court considered matters outside of the pleadings.
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493-94, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences, which can reasonably be drawn therefrom, must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Faile v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 539 (2002).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go to the fact finder.Â  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 717, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 59, 518 S.E.2d 301, 305 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  All ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party.Â  Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 120, 542 S.E.2d 736, 738 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied.Â  See Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 173-74, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Moreover, summary judgment is a drastic remedy, which should be cautiously invoked so no person will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed factual issues.Â Â  Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield, 349 S.C. 356, 363, 563 S.E.2d 331, 336 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The college claims the trial court erred in granting summary judgment because the South Carolina Consolidated Procurement Code, section 11-35-4230 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003), is not applicable to the negligence cause of action.Â  We disagree. 
Section 11-35-4230(1) provides â€œthe exclusive means of resolving a controversy between the State and a contractor or subcontractor,â€ which arises â€œunder or by virtue of a contract between them including, but not limited to, controversies based upon breach of contract, mistake, misrepresentation, or other cause for contract modification or recision.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The procedure set forth in the Procurement Code is the exclusive means of resolving a controversy, whether or not the parties voluntarily chose to proceed under the Code.Â  Unisys Corp. v. S.C. Budget & Control Bd., 346 S.C. 158, 170, 551 S.E.2d 263, 270 (2001).Â  According to the statute, a request for resolution of a contract controversy must be filed in writing to the appropriate chief procurement officer within one year of the date the requesting party first knows or should know of a latent defect.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-35-4230(2).Â Â Â Â  
 The contract between the college and Two State was for the construction of the Center and included a provision that the Procurement Code would â€œconstitute the exclusive means of resolving controversy between the State and a Contractor or Subcontractor.â€Â  Respondents allege the contract between the college and LS3P contained similar language.Â  However, this contract was not provided to this court in the Record on Appeal, though it is quoted by the trial court in its order granting the dismissal.Â  The terms of the contract between LS3P and Buford Goff stipulated disputes â€œbe resolved in the same manner as that provided for by the agreement between [the college] and [LS3P].â€Â  
The negligence cause of action for the failure of the HVAC system arose out of the contract between the parties; it was not a separate tort that existed outside of the contract.Â  See Unisys Corp., 346 S.C. at 170, 551 S.E.2d at 270 (finding the Procurement Code procedures applied to the Stateâ€™s claims for fraud in the inducement and punitive damages, even though the cause of action was not enumerated in the statute).Â  Even if the contracts did not provide for disposition of disputes through the Procurement Code, the statute applies.Â  Therefore, the college should have submitted a request for resolution of the controversy to the appropriate chief procurement officer in writing within one year of the date it first knew or should have known of the alleged negligence.Â  Because the college was required to exhaust its administrative remedies as a matter of law, summary judgment was proper.Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, the trial courtâ€™s decision is hereby
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J.,Â  CONCUR.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â

text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Christopher Dale Stepp, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-606
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 6, 2005Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia, Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Christopher Stepp appeals his convictions for trafficking of methamphetamines, use of a firearm during a violent crime, and possession with intent to distribute marijuana.Â  Specifically, Stepp argues the trial court erred failing to suppress evidence obtained by police in the search incident to arrest.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR and the following authorities: ISSUES 1 and 2: State v. Wannamaker, 346 S.C. 495, 499, 552 S.E.2d 284, 286 (2001) (holding an in limine ruling is not final and does not preserve the issue for appellate review); State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 149-50, 561 S.E.2d 640, 643-44 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding an in limine motion to suppress evidence must be renewed at the time the evidence is admitted into evidence); State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694-95 (2003) (stating that in order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge).Â  ISSUE 3: First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (stating Appellant was deemed to have abandoned an issue for which he failed to provide any argument or supporting authority).
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and BEATTY, J.J. concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Jenkins
text:
Screening Report / Proposed Opinion


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Dale Bruce Jenkins, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-607
Heard November 8, 2005 â€“ Filed December 6, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,Â  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia, and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dale Bruce Jenkins appeals following convictions for trafficking in cocaine and possession with intent to distribute cocaine within a half-mile of a school or park.Â  Specifically, he asserts the trial court erred in finding that his constitutional right not to testify was not violated by the solicitor during closing arguments.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In the evening hours of January 9, 2002, armed with a search warrant for Jenkinsâ€™ home, police waited outside his place of employment.Â  When Jenkins exited the building, officers took him into custody as he approached his vehicle.Â  As Jenkins was being detained, he was advised of his Miranda[1] rights.
The officers placed Jenkins in their car and drove to his home to execute the search warrant.Â  When they arrived at the residence, the officers discovered three other people inside, including Jenkinsâ€™ mother, an â€œolder gentleman,â€ and a small child.Â  While officers were searching the home, Glen Kufen, a Georgetown County Sheriffâ€™s officer, began speaking with Jenkins.Â  He told Jenkins that â€œdepending on where the narcotics [were] found in the house, everybody could go to jail or just him.â€Â  Kufen further informed him that if the drugs were found in his room, then only he would be held responsible.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Shortly after Jenkins was so advised, he told officer Kufen that they would find powder cocaine behind the door in his room.Â  Kufen entered Jenkinsâ€™ room, moved a pile of clothes, and pulled the carpet back to expose a plastic container housing a brown paper bag.Â  Two plastic bags containing cocaine were found inside the brown paper bag.Â  A SLED chemical analyst testified that one plastic bag contained 16.94 grams of cocaine and the other contained 4.98 grams.[2]Â  
A Georgetown County Grand Jury subsequently indicted Jenkins for trafficking in cocaine and possession with the intent to distribute cocaine within a half-mile radius of a school or park.Â  Jenkinsâ€™ case proceeded to trial in his absence on August 5, 2003.[3]
At the start of trial, the court held a Jackson v. Denno[4] hearing to determine whether Jenkins voluntarily gave his statement concerning the drugsâ€™ location.Â  Defense counsel argued the policeâ€™s statements that Jenkinsâ€™ mother and friend could go to jail depending on where the drugs were found essentially coerced Jenkins into talking.Â  Counsel posited that because Jenkins did not want his mother to go to jail, he was forced to tell where the drugs were; thus, the statement was not freely and voluntarily given.Â  
Following introduction of various testimony on the issue, the trial court found by a preponderance of the evidence that before the statement was made, Jenkins was fully apprised of his right to remain silent.Â  The court further found that the officerâ€™s statement concerning possible arrests was an accurate statement and, accordingly, there was no duress or threat to get Jenkins to talk.
Upon resolution of the Jackson v. Denno issue, the trial continued on the merits.Â  Following presentation of the Stateâ€™s case in chief, the defense rested without putting forward any additional evidence.Â  As such, the trial proceeded to closing statements.Â  At one point during the Stateâ€™s closing argument, in an effort to preempt a defense argument on the issue, the solicitor began to talk about whether Jenkinsâ€™ statement as to the drugsâ€™ location was given voluntarily.Â  To this end, the solicitor made the following comments:

Now comes the issue about, â€œWell, gee, he did force him or coerce him.Â  He told them unless he cooperated other people in the house would be arrested.â€Â  Well, the Judge is going to give you instructions in regard to possession that drugs can be possessed by more than one person, and what did the police officer tell him?Â  â€œIf the drugs are found in certain areas more than one person might be arrested.â€Â  Well if you walk into the living room and thereâ€™s three adults there and thereâ€™s drugs on the table, youâ€™re only going to arrest one person?
Think if you were to do that.Â  During the course of the trial all the Defendant would have to do is get on the stand and say, â€œIt wasnâ€™t mine.Â  It wasnâ€™t me.â€Â  The other two people arenâ€™t arrested - - -

(Emphasis added).
The solicitorâ€™s comments were cut off by defense counselâ€™s objection and the matter was heard in a bench conference.Â  At the conclusion of the conference, both parties were able to complete their closing arguments and the court charged the jury with the applicable law.Â  When the courtâ€™s charge was complete, the jury retired and defense counselâ€™s motion for a mistrial was addressed.Â  
Specifically, defense counsel argued that the solicitorâ€™s comments spoke to a personâ€™s ability to get on the stand and declare his or her innocence.Â  He further asserted that the comments were highly prejudicial and a violation of Jenkinsâ€™ Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.Â  This was especially true given the fact that Jenkins was not at trial and the solicitor pointed towards the witness stand when he made the comments.Â  
The court denied the mistrial because it found the comments were not directed at Jenkinsâ€™ failure to appear or failure to take the stand, but instead involved a hypothetical scenario.Â  The court further noted that its charge to the jury was clear that the attorneysâ€™ arguments were not in themselves evidence to be considered.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Jenkins argues â€œthe trial court erred in finding that appellantâ€™s constitutional rights to not testify and to rely entirely upon the presumption of innocence were not violatedâ€ by the solicitorâ€™s comments.Â  
Whether a solicitorâ€™s closing argument is proper is a matter left to the sound discretion of the trial court and an appellate court will not overturn a trial courtâ€™s decision concerning closing arguments unless there has been an abuse of that discretion.Â  State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 160, 561 S.E.2d 640, 649 (Ct. App. 2002) (citations omitted).
An accused has a constitutional right to remain silent, and exercise of that right may not be used against him.Â  See Doyle v. Ohio, 426 U.S. 610 (1976); State v. Shuler, 353 S.C. 176, 577 S.E.2d 438 (2003).Â  â€œSpecifically, the solicitor must not comment, whether directly or indirectly, on a defendantâ€™s silence, failure to testify, or failure to present a defense.â€Â  McFadden v. State, 342 S.C. 637, 640, 539 S.E.2d 391, 393 (2000).
When an alleged violation of this constitutional right has taken place, also referred to as a Doyle violation, the court must apply the harmless error analysis articulated in State v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 466 S.E.2d 364 (1996).Â  To be harmless under this analysis, the record should reflect that the reference to the defendantâ€™s right to silence was a single reference, not repeated or alluded to; that the defendantâ€™s silence was not connected directly to the defendantâ€™s exculpatory story; the defendantâ€™s story was completely implausible; and evidence of the defendantâ€™s guilt was overwhelming.Â  Id. at 531, 466 S.E.2d at 366.
Even assuming the solicitor made improper comments concerning the defendantâ€™s failure to testify, this alone does not automatically require reversal if the defendant is not prejudiced by the comments.Â  Gill v. State, 346 S.C. 209, 221, 552 S.E.2d 26, 33 (2001).Â  Furthermore, the defendant alleging the violation bears the burden of proving that the comments deprived him of a fair trial.Â  Id.  
In the current case, even if we decide that the statement could be seen as a comment on Jenkinsâ€™ failure to testify, we find it amounts to harmless error. Â When closing arguments were complete, the trial court charged the jury: â€œthe fact that the Defendant did not testify is not a factor to be considered by you in any way in your deliberation and in your consideration of the question of the guilt or innocence of the Defendant.â€Â  We find this charge sufficient to cure any potential errors.Â  See Johnson v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 188, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735-36 (1997) (holding any potential errors in solicitorâ€™s closing arguments were cured by trial courtâ€™s instruction to jury that it could not consider defendantâ€™s failure to testify).
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL, J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] See Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).
[2] Other evidence and drug paraphernalia found in Jenkinsâ€™ room included a digital scale, a pager, a cell phone, small plastic sandwich baggies, razor blades, and a Crown Royal bag containing money.
[3] The record on appeal does not indicate why Jenkins was absent.
[4] 378 U.S. 368 (1964).

title: State v. James
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Isiah James, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-608
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 8, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Isiah James, Jr. appeals his guilty plea on two counts of voluntary manslaughter each with sentences of thirty years and one count of armed robbery with a sentence of twenty-five years all to run consecutively. Â James argues the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction due to a defective indictment and that Judge King erred in denying Jamesâ€™ motion to challenge the denial of his co-defendantâ€™s motion for expungement.Â  After a thorough review of the record, counselâ€™s brief, and Jamesâ€™s pro se brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Jamesâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved. 
APPEAL DISMISSED. [1]

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Hayward
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John Wallace Hayward, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-609
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 8, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.

After a thorough review of the record and counselâ€™s brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Haywardâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved.

title: Browder v. Ross Marine
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David Browder, Respondent,
v.
Ross Marine, LLC, Swygert Shipyards, Inc., Arthur R.
Swygert, Jr., and Arthur R. Swygert, Sr., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-613
Heard November 6, 2005 â€“ Filed December 8, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William A. Scott, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Michael W. Sautter, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ross Marine, LLC, Swygert Shipyards, Inc., Sandblasters, Inc., Arthur Swygert, Jr., Arthur Swygert, Sr., and Cathy Spieghts (hereinafter collectively referred to as â€œRoss Marineâ€) appeal the trial courtâ€™s denial of their motion for a temporary injunction, arguing the trial court erred by not enjoining the law firm of Query, Sautter & Gliserman from representing David Browder in the present case.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In March 1993, Ross Marine hired David Browder as managing sales representative in charge of promoting the boat yard, maintaining contact with its customers, assuring customer satisfaction, and generally promoting goodwill between Ross Marine and its clients.Â  Browder signed an employment agreement containing a three year term.
During the initial stages of his employment, Browder recommended that Ross Marine retain the services of attorney Grady Query to handle the companyâ€™s periodic legal matters.Â  Browder was familiar with the quality of Queryâ€™s work because Query had represented Browder and his family for over twenty years.Â  Over the course of the next few years, Query and his present partner, Saul Gliserman, currently with the firm of Query, Sautter and Gliserman, LLC, represented Ross Marine in no less than seven different matters.Â  According to Arthur Swygert, Jr., president of Ross Marine, Browder was the primary contact between Ross Marine and its attorneys.Â  Invoices for legal services were sent in care of Browder and he met with the attorneys on numerous occasions on behalf of Ross Marine.Â  In furtherance of his employment, Browder â€œwas given full authority to discuss any matters and provide any and all information . . . needed in connection with their representation.â€ 
On September 12, 2000, Browder was terminated from his employment with Ross Marine.Â  In 2001, Browder commenced a Workersâ€™ Compensation proceeding against his former employer.Â  The law firm of Query, Sautter and Gliserman, LLC, (â€œthe Law Firmâ€) represented Browder in this matter.Â  Ross Marine did not lodge a conflict claim regarding this representation over the course of the Workersâ€™ Compensation proceedings.
On August 26, 2003, Browder filed a complaint against Ross Marine alleging, inter alia, breach of the partiesâ€™ written employment agreement.Â  Ross Marine answered and simultaneously moved to dismiss the action as well as compel arbitration pursuant to the contractâ€™s terms.Â  In addition, over three years after the filing of Browderâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim, Ross Marine notified Browder by letter that they were concerned about a potential conflict of interest regarding the Law Firmâ€™s present representation of Browder and prior representations of Ross Marine.Â  Browder promptly filed a motion for a hearing on the conflict issue.Â  Both partiesâ€™ motions were heard in January 2004.Â  The trial court ordered arbitration of the dispute but declined to rule on the conflict issue, stating that the parties should resolve the dispute among themselves.Â  Both partiesâ€™ subsequent motions to reconsider were denied.Â  Ross Marine appealed the trial courtâ€™s refusal to address the Law Firmâ€™s potential conflict.Â  By order dated June 16, 2004, this court dismissed the appeal as interlocutory.
In August 2004, Ross Marine filed a motion for a temporary injunction requesting that the case be enjoined from proceeding to arbitration until the issue regarding the Law Firmâ€™s representation of Browder was resolved.Â  Following a hearing on the motion, the trial court found Ross Marine failed to establish a conflict of interest regarding the Law Firmâ€™s prior representation of Ross Marine and offered no proof of irreparable harm if the injunctive relief was not granted.Â  Accordingly, the trial court denied Ross Marineâ€™s request for injunctive relief.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn order granting or denying an injunction is reviewed for abuse of discretion.â€Â  Strategic Resources Co. v. BCS Life Ins. Co., 2005 WL 1943536 at *1 (S.C. 2005).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Id.Â  Because an action seeking an injunction is in equity, an appellate court can find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Doe v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liability Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 347 S.C. 642, 645, 557 S.E.2d 670, 672 (2001).
DISCUSSION
Ross Marine argues the trial court erred in refusing to grant injunctive relief because the Law Firm has a conflict of interest arising from its prior representation of the appellants.Â  We disagree.
â€œGenerally, to obtain an injunction, a party must demonstrate irreparable harm, a likelihood of success on the merits, and an inadequate remedy at law.â€Â  Mailsource, LLC v. M.A. Bailey & Associates, Inc., 356 S.C. 363, 367-68, 588 S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision to deny the requested relief was largely based on the conclusion Ross Marine would not be successful on the merits of its conflict claims.Â  Pursuant to our standard of review, our decision hinges on whether this conclusion is supported by the evidence. 
Central to our analysis of whether the denial of injunctive relief was proper is the law of attorney conflicts regarding former clients.Â  Rule 1.9(a) of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, provides:

A lawyer who has formerly represented a client in a matter shall not thereafter represent another person in the same or a substantially related matter in which that personâ€™s interest are [sic] materially adverse to the interests of the former client unless the former client consents after consultation. (emphasis added)

â€œIn determining whether the matter is â€˜substantially related,â€™ one should consider, among other things, whether the affected lawyer â€˜would have or reasonably could have learned confidential information in the first representation that would be of significance in the second.â€™â€Â  Townsend v. Townsend, 323 S.C. 309, 317, 474 S.E.2d 424, 429 (1996) (quoting 1 Geoffrey C. Hazard, Jr. & W. William Hodes, The Law of Lawyering: A Handbook on the Model Rules of Professional Conduct Â§ 1.9:104, at 293 (1996)) (emphasis added).
Browderâ€™s current case against Ross Marine mainly involves issues of compensation, particularly bonuses and employment benefits he alleges are due him pursuant to his employment contract.Â  His pleadings do, however, allege wrongful termination of his employment contract, which, according to Browderâ€™s pleadings, limits termination to disloyal, dishonest, or unlawful conduct.Â  The cases in which Query represented Ross Marine were mainly collection matters, but include a dispute over completed work and a defective product case against a coatings manufacturer.
Ross Marineâ€™s primary support of its conflict claims are the affidavits of Arthur Swygert, Jr., one of which states, in rather conclusory fashion, â€œI believe that Grady Query and Saul Gliserman . . . learned valuable information regarding both David Browderâ€™s employment and the operations of Ross Marine that cause conflicts with their representation of David Browder against Ross Marine.â€Â  In a second affidavit, Swygert expounds on his previous allegation by describing three cases where the Law Firm represented Ross Marine.Â  Swygert asserts that these cases at least tangentially involved Browderâ€™s work performance.
None of the affidavits, however, aver that any confidential information was obtained by the Law Firm from any of the individual defendants or the corporation.Â  On the contrary, Ross Marine acknowledges that Browder was the primary contact between the company and its attorneys and does not allege how any information could have reasonably been gained in the prior representation that Browder could not simply convey to his attorney in his capacity as a current client.Â  Accordingly, the trial court found Ross Marine failed to establish a likelihood of success on the merits of their conflict claim.
After reviewing the record on appeal, we conclude the evidence supports this finding.Â  As stated in Madison v. Graffix Fabrix, Inc., 304 S.C. 321, 325-26, 404 S.E.2d 37, 40 (Ct. App. 1991):

[A]n attorney is not prevented from representing a subsequent client against a former client, where the duties required of him do not conflict with those required in the first employment.Â  The test of whether the attorneyâ€™s employment is inconsistent with his duty to a former client is whether acceptance of the new retainer will require him, in forwarding the interest of the new client, to do anything that will injuriously affect a former client in any matter in which he formerly represented him, and also whether the attorney will be called on, in his new relation, to use against a former client any knowledge or information acquired in the former relationship.

One year after the filing of Browderâ€™s complaint, Ross Marine failed to support its blanket allegations of attorney conflict with competent evidence showing confidential information regarding Browderâ€™s claims reasonably could have passed to the Law Firm during the previous representations.Â  Furthermore, Ross Marine failed to cogently articulate how any information in the prior representations is confidential or, for that matter, how it would be of significance in the present action.Â Â Â  Although the standard for determining conflicts against an attorneyâ€™s former clients requires only a minimal showing that the attorney â€œreasonably could haveâ€ learned confidential information, mere conclusory allegations that such information passed to the attorney, with nothing more, do not satisfy an attorney conflict claim. 
Because Ross Marine failed to establish a likelihood of success on the merits of their conflict claims, the trial courtâ€™s decision denying injunctive relief is
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and Â Â  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Bush v. SCDOC
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sandra Bush, Employee, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Corrections, Employer, and State Accident Fund, Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Dorchester County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-614
Â  Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 8, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Larry A. Welborn, of Anderson, for Appellant.
Matthew C. Robertson, Ajerenal Danley, and Cythia B. Polk, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, the single commissioner determined Sandra Bushâ€™s post-traumatic stress disorder was not an injury by accident arising out of and in the scope of her employment with the South Carolina Department of Corrections because she was not operating under unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment. An appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Commission) adopted the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  Bush appeals.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: Â Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co.,
360 S.C. 276, 289, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610-11 (Ct. App. 2004) (an appellate court must affirm the findings of the Commission if they are supported by substantial evidence); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2004) (â€œStress arising out of and in the course of employment unaccompanied by physical injury and resulting in mental illness or injury is not a personal injury unless it is established that the stressful employment conditions causing the mental injury were extraordinary and unusual in comparison to the normal conditions of the employment.â€); Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 456-57, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442-43 (2000) (holding that the requirement of â€œunusual or extraordinary conditions in employmentâ€ for a claimant to recover for a mental-mental injury refers to conditions to the particular job in which the injury occurs, not to conditions of employment in general); Doe v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Disabilities and Special Needs, 364 S.C. 411, 418, 613 S.E.2d 785, 789 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œIn order to recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits, Claimant must prove both: (1) that she was exposed to unusual and extraordinary conditions in her employment; and (2) that these unusual and extraordinary conditions were the proximate cause of her mental breakdown.â€). 
AFFIRMED.

STILWELL, KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1]  
Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant
Legal Director Teresa A. Knox, Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin and Legal Counsel Tommy Evans, Jr., all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from a revocation of Leonard A. Carterâ€™s probation.Â  Concerning the underlying offense, Carter appeared without counsel and pled guilty to one count of larceny less than five thousand dollars.Â  He was sentenced to five years, suspended upon service of ninety days, five years probation, concurrent to any other sentence he was serving, and was ordered to pay restitution.Â  Carter subsequently violated the conditions of his probation.Â  Carter, with the assistance of counsel, admitted the violations, and the court revoked his probation.Â  Carter appeals the probation revocation on the basis that he did not properly waive counsel at the underlying guilty plea.Â  This argument was not presented to the court at the probation revocation hearing. Carterâ€™s counsel at the revocation hearing merely alluded to Carterâ€™s prior, uncounseled plea and asked for â€œleniency.â€Â  Since the ground argued on appeal was not raised at the revocation hearing, it is not preserved for direct appellate review.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authority:Â  State v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 648, 511 S.E.2d 94, 96 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding that to preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the revocation judge).[1]
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Herring
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Heather R. Herring, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Dorchester County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court JudgeÂ Â Â  

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-616
 Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 8, 2005Â Â  

 AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor David M. Pascoe, Jr., of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Heather R. Herring pled guilty to resisting arrest. Â She was sentenced to one year imprisonment, suspended upon the service of two years probation. Â On appeal, Herring argues the court should vacate her guilty plea because the Stateâ€™s evidence does not provide a sufficient factual basis for her plea. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On May 27, 2004, Dorchester County police officers approached 129 Russell Street in Dorchester County with a bench warrant for Heather Herringâ€™s arrest. Â The officers had been informed that Herring was inside the Russell Street residence. Â After the officers entered the trailer, they called out loudly for Herring. Â Although Herring was inside, she did not answer the officersâ€™ calls.Â  Instead, she was hiding from the officers in the shower. Â The officers searched the residence and found Herring, fully clothed, in the master bathroom shower.
Herring pled guilty to resisting arrest. Â The Solicitor recommended two years probation. Â The Circuit Judge sentenced Herring to one year, suspended upon the service of two years probation.
DISCUSSION
Herring contends â€œ[t]he Stateâ€™s evidence does not provide a sufficient factual basis for Herringâ€™s guilty plea to a violation of S.C. Code Section 16-9-320(A).â€Â  Herringâ€™s assertion is meritless.
The usual colloquy occurred between the judge, Herring and defense counsel regarding whether Herring was knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily pleading guilty to the charges. Â The judge advised Herring as to her constitutional rights and waiver thereof, inquired into the circumstances of her guilty plea, fully explained the charges and sentencing consequences, and properly determined the plea was knowingly and voluntarily made.Â  Moreover, there was no objection during the guilty plea proceeding. Â Thus, Herring is barred from challenging her guilty plea on direct appeal.Â  See In the Interest of Antonio H., 324 S.C. 120, 477 S.E.2d 713 (1996) (proper avenue in which to challenge guilty plea which is not objected to at time of its entry is through post-conviction relief); State v. Williams, 303 S.C. 410, 401 S.E.2d 168 (1991) (defendant must object at first opportunity to preserve issue for appellate review; alleged error must be raised to and ruled on by trial judge); State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 292 S.E.2d 598 (1982) (absent timely objection at plea proceeding, unknowing and involuntary nature of guilty plea can be attacked only through more appropriate channel of post-conviction relief).
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, Herringâ€™s conviction and sentence are
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: The Gatherings Horizontal Property Regime v. Williams
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The Gatherings Horizontal Property Regime, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Bobby S. Williams, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis L. Coltrane, Master In Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-617
Heard November 8, 2005 â€“ Filed December 8, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Anthony E. Griffis and Sean Michael Bolchoz, both of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.Â  
        Edward E. Bullard and Sonja Friedman, both of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Bobby S. Williams appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order remanding this collection action to the magistrate for a new hearing because the transcription tape of the original hearing before the magistrate was destroyed.Â  We reverse and remand. 
FACTS
The Gatherings Horizontal Property Regime filed this action against Williams in magistrateâ€™s court for past-due regime fees allegedly owed by the previous owner of Williamsâ€™ condominium, Audress Hill.Â  A concurrently pending action against Hill was dismissed with prejudice when Hill paid the fees.Â  The magistrate concluded any further attempt by The Gatherings to collect from Williams was barred by res judicata. Â By order dated April 7, 2004, the magistrate accordingly dismissed The Gatheringsâ€™ action against Williams and awarded Williams an attorneyâ€™s fee of $3,000.Â  The magistrate denied The Gatheringsâ€™ motion for reconsideration.Â  The Gatherings appealed the magistrateâ€™s order to circuit court and served the magistrate.Â  
The Gatherings alleges it made numerous telephone calls to the magistrateâ€™s office requesting the trial tape be retained.Â  When the tape was not made available, The Gatherings requested a hearing in circuit court.Â  The circuit court issued an order requiring the magistrate to certify the original record to the circuit court and to allow transcription of the tape.Â  
When the magistrate failed to comply with the transcription portion of the order, the circuit court issued an order requiring the magistrate to appear to show cause why he should not be held in contempt.Â  Prior to a hearing on the matter, the magistrate informed the circuit court that the hearing tape had been reused and was unavailable for transcription.Â  The magistrate asserts he reused the tape because he believed the time for filing a notice of appeal had expired. Â The circuit court held a hearing on the issue of the magistrateâ€™s contempt and sua sponte issued an order:Â  â€œBecause the tape . . . is no longer available, the Plaintiff is unable to complete the record on appeal, and therefore this case is remanded to the Magistrateâ€™s court for a new trial.â€Â  Williams appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section 22-3-10 of the South Carolina Code gives concurrent jurisdiction to the circuit courts and to magistrates in contract actions.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-10(1) (Supp. 2004).Â  Our code also provides that the circuit courts have appellate jurisdiction over cases initially heard by a magistrate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 14-5-340 (1977) & 18-7-170 (1985).Â  The circuit court, sitting in an appellate capacity, may reverse a judgment for errors of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 18-7-140 & -170 (1985); Vacation Time of Hilton Head Island, Inc. v. Kiwi Corp., 280 S.C. 232, 234, 312 S.E.2d 20, 21 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Our scope of review, however, is more limited:Â  

  [T]he Court of Appeals will presume that an affirmance by a Circuit Court of a magistrateâ€™s judgment was made upon the merits where the testimony is sufficient to sustain the judgment of the magistrate and there are no facts that show the affirmance was influenced by an error of law . . . .

Burns v. Wannamaker, 281 S.C. 352, 357, 315 S.E.2d 179, 182 (Ct. App. 1984), affâ€™d as modified on other grounds, 288 S.C. 398, 343 S.E.2d 27 (1985).Â  This court may reverse the circuit court if it was influenced by an error of law.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Williams argues the circuit court erred by remanding the case for a new trial rather than requesting an amended return from the magistrate.Â  We agree.Â  Section 18-7-60 of the South Carolina Code applies to appeals from magistrateâ€™s court and directs the magistrate, â€œafter ten days and within thirty days after service of the notice of appeal, [to] make a return to the appellate court of the testimony, proceedings and judgment and file it in the appellate court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-60 (1985).Â  
Section 18-7-80 supplies the remedy when the magistrateâ€™s return is inadequate by providing:Â  â€œIf the return be defective the appellate court may direct a further or amended return as often as may be necessary and may compel a compliance with its order.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-80 (1985).Â  Whether to direct a further amended return is discretionary with the circuit court.Â  Lynch v. Heyward, 56 S.C. 562, 565, 35 S.E. 220, 221 (1900). 
We find guidance from Chapman v. Computers, Parts & Repairs, 334 S.C. 387, 513 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In Chapman, the circuit court sua sponte reversed and remanded the action for a new trial based on the magistrateâ€™s inadequate return.Â  Id. at 389, 513 S.E.2d at 121.Â  This court reversed and remanded finding the circuit court violated the terms of section 18-7-80.Â  Id. at 391-92, 513 S.E.2d at 122-23.Â  This court found the remand for a new trial effectively punished the party who prevailed in magistrateâ€™s court, and that the circuit court should have sought an amended return instead of remanding the matter for a new trial.Â  Id. at 391, 513 S.E.2d at 122.
In criminal proceedings before a magistrate, the legislature has provided a right to a tape or transcription of testimony.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-790 (1989) (requiring testimony of witnesses in criminal action before a magistrate to be â€œtaken down in writing and signed by the witnessesâ€ unless waived).Â  However, there is no corresponding requirement in civil proceedings.Â  
We are, however, mindful of our supreme courtâ€™s opinion in McKinley Music v. Glymph.Â  100 S.C. 200, 84 S.E. 715 (1915).Â  In Glymph, the supreme court addressed the issue of the magistrateâ€™s failure to â€œtake downâ€ testimony.Â  The circuit court in Glymph ordered a new trial because the defendantâ€™s testimony was not â€œfully taken down.â€Â  Id. at 202, 84 S.E. at 716.Â  The supreme court affirmed, finding â€œ[a]n amended or further return by the magistrate would not have been effective to supply testimony which had not been â€˜taken down.â€™â€Â  Id. 
The facts in this case are distinguishable from those in Glymph.Â  In Glymph, the court apparently needed a more detailed report of the proceeding prior to reviewing the case.Â  Here, it appears the material facts are undisputed and the case is primarily based on issues of law, not fact.Â  The applicable contracts and documents are included in the record.Â  The magistrateâ€™s order is unambiguous and provides a comprehensive recitation of the proceeding.Â  In such a case, a transcription of the partiesâ€™ testimony appears less likely to be necessary to resolve the issues.Â  However, we leave it to the circuit courtâ€™s discretion as to whether an amended return is required.Â  
CONCLUSION
After a review of relevant law, we find the circuit court erred in this case by reversing and remanding for a new trial on the ground stated.Â  We accordingly reverse and remand to the circuit court to receive an amended return from the magistrate, if necessary, and decide the appeal on its merits.[1]
REVERSED AND REMANDED.Â  
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  Based on our disposition, we decline to address Williamsâ€™ remaining issue on appeal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

v.

Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-618
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 9, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor C. Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jason Smith Roberts appeals his guilty plea to one count of possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute and one count of possession of marijuana with intent to distribute, alleging the trial court erred in accepting his guilty plea without fully advising him of his constitutional rights.Â  Counsel for Roberts attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Roberts did not file a separate pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Robertsâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.[1]
APPEAL DISMISSED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  Dennis E. Selmon appeals his convictions and sentences for two counts of distribution of cocaine and one count of distribution of cocaine within the proximity of a school.Â  Selmon also appeals his conviction and sentence for one count of distribution of cocaine.Â  Selmonâ€™s counsel argues the plea court failed to comply with the mandates set forth in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969), because Selmon was not informed he could have alleged certain defenses, including entrapment.Â  Counsel for Selmon attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Selmon did not file a separate pro se response.
After a thorough review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Selmonâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.[1]Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.

v.

  
    
      
        Christopher Ryan Nalley, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-620
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 9, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant.Â  
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Christopher Nalley appeals his conviction for receiving and having in possession stolen goods valued greater than ten thousand dollars.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State v. Carlson, 363 S.C. 586, 595, 611 S.E.2d 283, 287 (Ct. App. 2005) (finding issue not preserved where defendantâ€™s counsel stated he had no objection to admission of evidence); Doe v. S.B.M., 327 S.C. 352, 356, 488 S.E.2d 878, 880 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding that a contemporaneous objection is â€œrequired to properly preserve an error for appellate reviewâ€); Cogdill v. Watson, 289 S.C. 531, 537, 347 S.E.2d 126, 130 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œThe failure to make an objection at the time evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to object.â€). 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
