THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Paul Mazzell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 2005-UP-621
Heard November 7, 2005 â€“ Filed December 9, 2005Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Michael W. Sautter and O. Grady Query, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Paul Mazzell was convicted in 1983 of murder, criminal conspiracy, and kidnapping.Â  He appeals the circuit courtâ€™s denial of his 1997 motion for a new trial based upon after-discovered evidence.Â  We affirm.
 FACTS
Ricky Seagraves was abducted and murdered near Charleston in 1978. The police did not recover his body until 1981, when investigators received information from Danny Hogg.Â  Hogg admitted he participated in Seagravesâ€™ abduction, but he also implicated Mazzell and Edward Merriman in the crime.Â  In exchange for immunity from prosecution for his role in the abduction and other crimes, Hogg agreed to testify against Mazzell and Merriman.Â  Additionally, Hogg led investigators to the site where Seagravesâ€™ body was buried.
The State sought the death penalty against Mazzell, who Hogg identified as the triggerman in the murder.Â  Mazzell was tried along with his co-defendant Merriman.Â  The State maintained that Seagraves, Hogg, and Merriman all worked for Mazzell.Â  Allegedly, they were all connected to the Charleston drug trade.Â  The State presented evidence that Mazzell wanted Seagraves killed; therefore, he instructed Hogg and Merriman to abduct and deliver Seagraves to him, and then he killed Seagraves.
Hogg testified that Mazzell put a contract on Seagravesâ€™ life.Â  According to Hogg, Mazzell announced, â€œGo get Ricky. Bring him to me. Iâ€™m going to kill him.â€ Hogg and Merriman located Seagraves at a convenience store near Charleston.Â  Hogg testified he heard a gunshot and saw Merriman chase Seagraves into the convenience store.Â  Seagraves was then beaten, dragged back to the truck, and delivered to Mazzell.Â  Mazzell allegedly killed Seagraves and buried his body.Â  Two witnesses corroborated Hoggâ€™s version of the incident.Â  Carl Hines testified that Mazzell declared in late 1978 that he intended to kill Seagraves, and Mazzell later boasted that he had killed him.Â  Harold Behrens also testified that Merriman recounted the abduction and murder to him, giving a description that was consistent with Hoggâ€™s testimony.
In defense, Mazzell brought out Hinesâ€™ and Behrensâ€™ past criminal activity and noted that numerous prosecution witnesses received special treatment from the State in exchange for their testimony.Â  Mazzellâ€™s attorney particularly assailed Hoggâ€™s credibility by presenting witnesses who testified that Hogg and Mazzell had a falling out.Â  They also testified that Hogg said he would get back at Mazzell by killing him or putting him in jail.Â  Two defense witnesses specifically claimed Hogg admitted he shot and killed Seagraves.Â  
Additionally, Mazzellâ€™s wife testified that Hogg was at their home on the night of Seagravesâ€™ abduction and that he stated he intended to find Seagraves.Â  She also provided alibi testimony for Mazzell, stating that she and Mazzell went to bed early that night, after watching television at home.Â  Mazzell did not take the stand to offer testimony in his defense.Â  
In February 1983, a jury convicted Mazzell of murder, criminal conspiracy, and kidnapping.Â  The jury recommended life in prison instead of the death penalty as requested by the State.[1]
Mazzell filed a direct appeal, along with his co-defendant Merriman, in which he raised numerous improprieties and misconduct by the State and the prosecutor.Â  Additionally, he argued for a new trial because the court refused to allow into evidence the fact Hogg had to take a polygraph test as part of his immunity agreement.Â  
This court found some of the allegations of police threats and intimidation to be without evidence, and found the deliberate release of misinformation to the media to be â€œhorrendous and ridiculous,â€ but found it did not affect the trial in a prejudicial manner.Â  State v. Merriman, 287 S.C. 74, 79-80, 337 S.E.2d 218, 222 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  This court also found the trial courtâ€™s curative instruction, after the prosecutors had elicited improper testimony, was sufficient to remedy any harm it caused.Â  Id. at 83, 337 S.E.2d at 224.Â  Finally, the court found the refusal to admit the entire immunity agreement, especially the portion regarding the polygraph testing, was proper given the general inadmissibility of the polygraph test and the fact that it would be cumulative to other evidence in the record.Â  Id. at 87-88, 337 S.E.2d at 226-27.Â  Thereafter, the South Carolina Supreme Court denied Mazzellâ€™s petition for writ of certiorari.Â  
In 1988, Mazzell filed an application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  In his application, he claimed, among other things, that Merriman testified at his own PCR action that Hogg committed the murder and not Mazzell.Â  He maintained this testimony was unavailable at the original trial because Merriman asserted his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.Â  The court denied PCR relief and Mazzellâ€™s separate petition for a writ of certiorari was also denied.
Mazzell then filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus with the United States District Court for South Carolina in 1990.Â  The petition was granted by the District Court in 1995 on the grounds that Mazzellâ€™s attorney failed to object to erroneous jury instructions.Â  The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed this decision.Â  Mazzell v. Evatt, 88 F.3d 263 (4th Cir. 1996).Â  On remand to the district court, Mazzelâ€™s petition for writ of habeas corpus was denied.
In January 1997, Mazzell filed the underlying motion for a new trial.Â  In November 2000, Mazzell filed to have access to the prosecutionâ€™s file for inspection of its documents and noted the disappearance of SLEDâ€™s investigative file.Â  At the hearing on his new trial motion, Mazzell asserted that several possible witness interviews brought to light new evidence that exonerated him.Â  Additionally, he maintained the court should consider polygraph evidence regarding himself, Merriman, and Hogg.Â  He also argued that several items contained in the prosecutionâ€™s file were new evidence because he alleged they were not turned over to defense counsel.Â  Finally, Mazzell maintained prosecutorial misconduct, combined with the evidence brought forth at the hearing, justified a new trial. Â The parties each submitted a post-hearing memorandum.Â  Mazzell also filed a Motion for Alternative Consideration of Evidence as Warranting Issuance of the Writ of Habeas Corpus.
The trial judge requested an order from the Attorney Generalâ€™s office.Â  Mazzellâ€™s counsel filed objections to the proposed order; therefore, the judge entered his own order in which he detailed the procedural and factual history of the case.Â  The order then stated:

  In Hayden v. State, the South Carolina Supreme Court reviewed the criteria necessary to grant a new trial on newly discovered evidence.Â  The Court explained:Â  â€œ[a] party requesting a new trial based on after-discovered evidence must show that the evidence:Â  (1) is such as would probably change the result if a new trial was had; (2) has been discovered since the trial; (3) could not by the exercise of due diligence have been discovered before the trial; (4) is material to the issue of guilt or innocence; and, (5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.â€Â  [Hayden v. State, 299 S.E.2d 854 (S.C. 1983) (citing State v. Caskey, 256 S.E.2d 737 (S.C. 1979)).]Â  The applicant failed to satisfy any of the above criteria and his Motion is Denied.

This appeal followed.

 STANDARD OF REVIEW 
â€œThe denial of a motion for a new trial will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State v. South, 310 S.C. 504, 507, 427 S.E.2d 666, 668 (1993).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.â€Â  State v. Hughes, 346 S.C. 339, 342, 552 S.E.2d 35, 36 (Ct. App. 2001).
 LAW/ANALYSIS 
 I.Â Â Trial Courtâ€™s Order  

        Mazzell contends this court should remand the case to the trial court because the trial judge failed to provide sufficient findings of fact and conclusions of law in the order denying Mazzellâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  We disagree.
        The trial judgeâ€™s order, while brief, was complete.Â  It provided a statement of the grounds the judge considered, as well as the standard under which he considered the alleged new evidence.Â  The judge then specifically found:Â  â€œThe applicant failed to satisfy any of the above criteria and his motion is denied.â€ Â Therefore, we find the order did not fail to provide sufficient findings of fact and conclusions of law because the trial judgeâ€™s decision can be adequately reviewed by this court for a determination of whether he abused his discretion in denying Mazzell a new trial based on after-discovered evidence.
        II.Â Â After-Discovered Evidence
        Mazzell asserts he is entitled to a new trial because of the after-discovered evidence he put forth at the new trial hearing.Â  
        Pursuant to Rule 29(b), SCRCrimP: 
        
          A motion for a new trial based on after-discovered evidence must be made within a reasonable period of time after the discovery of the evidence; provided, however, that a motion for a new trial based on after-discovered evidence may not be made while the case is on appeal unless the appellate court, upon motion, has suspended the appeal and granted leave to make the motion.Â Â  
        
        To obtain a new trial based on after-discovered evidence, the party must show that the evidence:Â  1) would probably change the result if a new trial were granted; 2) has been discovered since trial; 3) could not have in the exercise of due diligence been discovered before trial; 4) is material to the issue of guilt or innocence; and 5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.Â  State v. Spann, 334 S.C. 618, 619-20, 513 S.E.2d 98, 99 (1999).
        A.Â Â Merriman testimony and polygraph
        Mazzell asserts the testimony provided by Merriman at Merrimanâ€™s PCR hearing constitutes after-discovered evidence.Â  We disagree.
        Evidence presented, which was known to the defendant at the time of his trial, cannot be considered â€œnew evidenceâ€ for purposes of receiving a new trial.Â  See Hayden v. State, 278 S.C. 610, 612, 299 S.E.2d 854, 855-56 (1983).Â  Additionally, because an individual refuses to testify at trial does not make his later testimony new evidence.Â  See, e.g., United States v. Dale, 991 F.2d 819, 839 (D.C. Cir. 1993) (finding majority of circuits considering the issue have found testimony is not new evidence because the declarant refused to testify at trial).
         At Mazzellâ€™s PCR hearing, Merriman testified that Hogg killed Seagraves.Â  He also stated Mazzell never ordered them to find Seagraves or to bring Seagraves to him. Â He explained that Seagraves was dead before they delivered him to Mazzell, though he admitted he did not know for certain that he was dead.Â  The PCR court found his testimony lacked credibility and denied Mazzellâ€™s request for PCR relief based on the alleged after-discovered evidence.
        Merriman died prior to the new trial motion hearing and several former investigators testified regarding conversations with Merriman.Â  SLED Agent Lovat Faircloth testified that in 1987 Merriman indicated Hogg killed Seagraves.Â  Faircloth stated Merriman told him Mazzell was only involved in the disposal of the body.
        Evidence was presented that in 1993 Merriman told SLED Agent Ron Cook that â€œhe is almost positive that Ricky Seagraves was dead by the time they arrived at the houseâ€ and that he never saw Mazzell at the house or knew what happened after he left.Â  Cook reported that Merriman stated Hogg killed Seagraves and Merriman was with him when Hogg shot Seagraves.
        Additionally, in 1993, Merriman took a polygraph test to verify that he witnessed Hogg shoot Seagraves and that he did not witness Mazzell shoot Seagraves.Â  The polygraph report indicates no deception on Merrimanâ€™s part.
        First, this evidence is not new evidence because Mazzell knew it at the time of trial.Â  Additionally, it is not likely to change the result.Â  Merriman testified he did not know for certain that Seagraves was dead.Â  He also told investigators he did not know what happened after he left the house or where they took Seagraves.Â  Hogg testified at trial that Merriman was not present when Mazzell shot Seagraves.Â  Although Merrimanâ€™s testimony that he did not know what happened to Seagraves is confirmed by a polygraph, it is not likely to change the result of the trial.Â  Accordingly, we find Merrimanâ€™s testimony and polygraph are insufficient to support a claim for a new trial based upon after-discovered evidence.
        B.Â Thaddeus Mazzell testimony
        Mazzell contends the testimony of his brother, Thaddeus Mazzell, is new evidence warranting a new trial because the testimony exonerates him for the murder of Seagraves.Â  We disagree.
        Thaddeus refused to testify at Mazzellâ€™s new trial hearing unless he was given immunity.Â  As a result, Mazzell introduced testimony by his attorneys relating to information given to them by Thaddeus.Â  Additionally, Officer Melvin Ballew testified about his interviews of Thaddeus on two separate occasions.
        Ballew testified he interviewed Thaddeus in 1993 and 1996.Â  In 1993, Ballew testified Thaddeus told him that â€œhe was present when Danny Hogg was at [Mazzellâ€™s] house earlier that evening; that he wanted to go get - - wanted to try to find Ricky and that Paul told him to leave Ricky alone.â€Â  According to Ballew, Thaddeus said he and Mazzell were both present when Hogg and Merriman delivered the body to the house.Â  Thaddeus told Ballew that Seagraves was â€œdead as a hammer.â€ 
        Ballew testified that at the second interview in 1996, Thaddeus relayed a similar story regarding the events on the night of Seagravesâ€™ murder.Â  Additionally, Ballew stated that Thaddeus told him Hogg and Seagraves had â€œan ongoing feudâ€ and that was why Hogg wanted to get Seagraves.
        Mazzellâ€™s attorney, Keir Weyble, also testified about an interview he had with Thaddeus in 2001.Â  He described similar statements by Thaddeus regarding the events of the night of the murder.Â  He stated Thaddeus told him that he received a call from Mazzell to pick up Mazzell because Hogg â€œgot Ricky [Seagraves].â€ Â According to Weyble, Thaddeus explained that as he and Mazzell were walking up the driveway, Hogg and Merriman arrived with â€œwhat they later found out was the dead body of Ricky Seagraves.â€Â  Weyble testified: â€œThaddeusâ€™ description of Mr. Seagraves at that time was that he was, and I remember this quote because it struck me, â€˜dead as a hammer when he hit the ground.â€™â€Â  Finally, he relayed Thaddeusâ€™ statement that he and Mazzell disposed of the body. 
        First, the evidence must have been discovered since the trial and could not have, in the exercise of due diligence, been discovered before trial.Â  Spann, 334 S.C. at 619, 513 S.E.2d at 99.Â  This evidence fails both requirements because the testimony clearly indicates Mazzell should have had knowledge of the testimony as Thaddeus testified he and Mazzell were both present when Seagraves was â€œdelivered.â€Â  Additionally, Mazzell claimed in his â€œApplication for Federal Habeasâ€ relief that one of the claims in his PCR application was â€œ[t]he applicantâ€™s trial counsel unreasonably failed to call Thaddeus Mazzell as a defense witness, despite the fact that Thaddeus Mazzell was available and his testimony would have exculpated the applicant.â€[2] 
        It is unlikely that this testimony would have changed the result of the trial.Â  Both Ballew and Weyble indicated that Thaddeus never ensured Seagraves was dead when Hogg delivered his body.Â  The testimony presented at trial indicated Seagraves was hurt when Hogg and Merriman abducted him from the convenience store.Â  Nothing in Thaddeusâ€™ testimony indicates that Seagraves was not merely unconscious when he was removed from the truck.Â  
        Finally, the testimony of Thaddeus lacks sufficient credibility to determine that it would have changed the outcome of the trial.Â  See Hayden, 278 S.C. at 612, 299 S.E.2d at 855-56 (finding the credibility of a witness is a factor in determining whether testimony will likely change the result at the new trial).Â  Thaddeus is Mazzellâ€™s brother and was admittedly involved in the disposal of the body.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to grant a new trial based on the proposed testimony of Thaddeus Mazzell.
        C.Â Pre-trial Statements by Lisa Hogg and William Poindexter
        Mazzell contends the Stateâ€™s suppression of pre-trial statements by Lisa Hogg and William Poindexter requires a new trial.Â  He also contends this evidence constitutes newly discovered evidence because it was not turned over by the State before trial.Â  We disagree.
        We must first discuss the implications of Mazzellâ€™s claims under Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963), and Rule 5, SCRCrimP.Â  â€œA Brady claim is based upon the requirement of due process.Â  Such a claim is complete if the accused can demonstrate (1) the evidence was favorable to the accused, (2) it was in the possession of or known to the prosecution, (3) it was suppressed by the prosecution, and (4) it was material to guilt or punishment.â€Â  Gibson v. State, 334 S.C. 515, 524, 514 S.E.2d 320, 324 (1999).Â  Rule 5 requires:Â  
        
          Upon request of the defendant the prosecution shall permit the defendant to inspect and copy books, papers, documents, . . . , or copies or portions thereof, which are within the possession, custody or control of the prosecution, and which are material to the preparation of his defense or are intended for use by the prosecution as evidence in chief at the trial, or were obtained from or belong to the defendant.
        
        Rule 5(a)(1)(C), SCRCrimP.Â  
        At Mazzellâ€™s PCR hearing, the prosecutor testified he received a motion for disclosure of the prosecutionâ€™s documents from Mazzellâ€™s counsel and he made the Stateâ€™s file available to him.Â  Mazzell has not presented any evidence to refute this assertion by the prosecutor, nor was this statement challenged after the PCR hearing.Â  The only evidence in the record indicates the State complied with the requirement to turn over the evidence to the defense.Â  Moreover, at trial, Mazzellâ€™s counselâ€™s cross-examination of Hogg supports a strong inference that Mazzell was aware of this information.Â  
        Next, we must determine if either document meets the requirements of State v. Spann, 334 S.C. 618, 619-20, 513 S.E.2d 98, 99 (1999), as after-discovered evidence sufficient to warrant a new trial.Â  The first document is the prosecutionâ€™s interview sheet with Lisa Hogg.Â  In the interview as recorded on the sheet under the category â€œPROBLEMS,â€ Lisa indicated Hogg did the killing and â€œsaid it was all a big accident.â€Â  Additionally, the notes on the interview sheet read:Â  â€œThat Ricky started shooting.Â  Hid body at ballpark.Â  That Ricky fired first.â€Â  Under the column â€œSTRATEGYâ€ the sheet reads â€œDonâ€™t C,â€ which is struck through three times.
        The second document is a written statement given by William Poindexter.Â  In his statement, Poindexter asserts that only Hogg came to visit Harry Chestnut at work to discuss something out of his earshot.Â  He testified it was the only time he saw Hogg and Chestnut together while Chestnut was working for him.Â  Poindexterâ€™s statement contradicts testimony given at trial by Chestnut and Hogg that Hogg, Merriman, and Mazzell all met with Chestnut at the job site and discussed the whereabouts of Seagraves.
        As discussed above, according to the prosecutor, both documents were made available to Mazzell prior to trial.Â  As such, they cannot be considered after-discovered evidence.Â  Additionally, Mazzellâ€™s counsel cross-examined Hogg regarding whether he told Lisa that he killed and buried Seagraves.Â  He was also cross-examined about any conversations he had with Lisa about Seagraves firing shots at Hogg first.Â  It appears the information contained in the Lisaâ€™s interview sheet and Poindexterâ€™s written statement was clearly available to the defense at the time of the trial.Â  Accordingly, we find the evidence is not after-discovered evidence as required by Spann.
        D.Â  Polygraph Results of Mazzell, Merriman, and Hogg
        Mazzell contends the polygraph results of Mazzell, Merriman, and Hogg constitute new evidence and should, in conjunction with the testimonial evidence, be sufficient to grant him a new trial.Â  We disagree.
        Even if a new trial is granted, the newly discovered evidence must be admissible in the new trial.Â  Our supreme court has often held the results of polygraph examinations are generally not admissible because the reliability of the tests is questionable.Â  See State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 23-24, 515 S.E.2d 508, 519-20 (1999); see also, State v. Wright, 322 S.C. 253, 471 S.E.2d 700 (1996); State v. Copeland, 278 S.C. 572, 300 S.E.2d 63 (1982).Â  
        In South Carolina, the court must evaluate scientific evidence under Rule 702, SCRE[3], and the factors established in State v. Jones, 273 S.C. 723, 731-32, 259 S.E.2d 120, 124-25 (1979).Â  â€œIn considering the admissibility of scientific evidence under the Jones standard, the Court looks at several factors, including:Â  (1) the publications and peer review of the technique; (2) prior application of the method to the type of evidence involved in the case; (3) the quality control procedures used to ensure reliability; and (4) the consistency of the method with recognized scientific laws and procedures.Â  Council, 335 S.C. at 19, 515 S.E.2d at 517.
        Mazzell offered the testimony of Timothy Williams, a polygraph examiner, to establish the requirements of Jones.Â  Williams testified that there have been conclusive studies done to establish the reliability rates of polygraph examinations.Â  Additionally, he described the quality control procedures used by various examiners to insure the accuracy of the exam.Â  However, Williams admitted there is dispute in the community about which techniques of quality control to use.Â  He consented that the reliability rates were established in laboratory settings and were not obtained from research of real-life polygraph exams. Â Finally, he stated there is at least one manual detailing how to defeat a polygraph test.
        We find the testimony by Williams fails to establish the polygraphâ€™s admissibility under Jones.Â  The testimony establishes that much of the exam is â€œartâ€ and not â€œscienceâ€ and subject to the interpretations of the examiner.Â  His testimony indicated, and he admitted, that an examiner could challenge the results of another examiner.Â  We conclude Williams has failed to identify a consistent and accepted testing standard.Â  Therefore, we find the results of the polygraphs administered in this case do not meet the requirements of Rule 702 and Jones.
        Even if this court were to conclude the polygraphs could be admitted at a new trial, they were merely cumulative to other evidence or impeaching of the Stateâ€™s witnesses and do not speak to Mazzellâ€™s guilt or innocence.Â  The defense spent considerable effort to discredit Hogg as a State witness, as this court found in Mazzellâ€™s direct appeal on whether the polygraph of Hogg should be admitted in conjunction with the immunity agreement: 
        
          Finally, we are of the opinion that the polygraph results would not in any reasonable likelihood have affected the judgment of the jury as to Mazzellâ€™s guilt or innocence.Â  [citation omitted]Â  Mazzell apparently sought admission of the polygraph agreement and results to attack Hoggâ€™s credibility as a witness and to show Hogg actually killed Seagraves.Â  However, Hoggâ€™s credibility was thoroughly impeached by other evidence, including his past criminal record, his own admission that he had given false testimony in a previous trial, and his admission that he was testifying in exchange for immunity which would be revoked if he turned out to be the triggerman in the Seagraves murder.Â  The solicitor himself acknowledged to the jury that Hogg was not a believable person.Â  Admission of the results of Hoggâ€™s polygraph examination would have been merely cumulative to the other evidence impeaching his credibility.Â  Likewise other evidence was presented to the jury to prove Hogg killed Seagraves.Â  Three witnesses testified that Hogg admitted he shot Seagraves.Â  This testimony, had the jury believed it, was far better evidence of Hoggâ€™s guilt than results of a polygraph which â€œindicated deception.â€Â Â Â  
        
        Merriman, 287 S.C. at 88, 337 S.E.2d at 226-27.Â  The same conclusion can be reached in regards to Merrimanâ€™s and Mazzellâ€™s polygraphs.Â  Accordingly, we find the polygraph evidence fails the requirements for granting a new trial based upon after-discovered evidence.
        III.Â Alternative Consideration for Writ of Habeas Corpus
        Mazzell contends the trial court erred in failing to view his motion as a petition for a writ of habeas corpus and in not granting relief.Â  We disagree.
        Pursuant to Gibson v. State, 329 S.C. 37, 41, 495 S.E.2d 426, 428 (1998), habeas corpus is available only when other remedies, such as Post-Conviction Relief, are inadequate or unavailable.Â  Additionally, in Simpson v. State, 329 S.C. 43, 46, 495 S.E.2d 429, 431 (1998), the South Carolina Supreme Court held a petition for a writ of habeas corpus cannot be used as a substitute for an action under the Uniform Post-Conviction Procedure Act.Â  Finally, in Simpson, the court concluded, â€œa matter which is cognizable under the Act may not be raised by a petition for a writ of habeas corpus before the circuit or other lower courts.â€Â  Id.
        The contentions raised by Mazzell could be considered for relief other than habeas corpus.Â  The allegations of misconduct were raised on direct appeal and considered by this court.Â  Consideration of his new trial evidence was made pursuant to his motion under Rule 29, SCRCrimP, or could be raised in PCR.Â  Because Mazzell had other remedies and failed to explain why those remedies were either unavailable or inadequate, the trial court did not err in refusing to grant Mazzellâ€™s alternate request for the issuance of a writ of habeas corpus.
        AFFIRMED.
    HEARN, C.J., SHORT, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur. 

[1] The above facts are taken from the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals opinion in Mazzell v. Evatt, 88 F.3d 263, 265-66 (1996).
[2] It does not appear to us that this claim was actually raised by Mazzell in his PCR application; however, the allegation in his petition for habeas relief would still provide evidence that the testimony was not â€œafter-discovered evidenceâ€ sufficient to warrant a new trial.
[3] Rule 702 states:Â  â€œIf scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€

title: Southeastern Realty and Construction, Inc. v. Burdge
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Southeastern Realty and Construction, Inc., Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Myron Burdge and Judy Burdge, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â C. Allen Gibson, Jr., Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-622
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 9, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Jon L. Austen, Ian W. Freeman, of Charleston; for Appellants.
        John P. Seibels, Jr., of Charleston; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Myron and Judy Burdge (â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal the special refereeâ€™s order denying their request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs made pursuant to a mechanicâ€™s lien filed by Southeastern Realty and Construction, Inc. (â€œSoutheasternâ€).Â  As the prevailing party, the Burdges claim they are entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees despite the dismissal of the mechanicâ€™s lien due to Southeasternâ€™s failure to file a lis pendens.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
FACTS
On September 30, 1999, the Burdges entered into a contract with Southeastern for the construction of a residence on Wadmalaw Island.Â  The parties agreed on a contract price of $838,979 and a period of eleven months for substantial completion of the project. 
On October 9, 2001, Southeastern filed a mechanicâ€™s lien, alleging the Burdges owed $107,782.42 on the contract, which included change orders.Â  Shortly thereafter, Southeastern filed a complaint, seeking to foreclose on the mechanicâ€™s lien and alleging a cause of action for breach of contract.Â  The Burdges answered and counterclaimed, asserting causes of action for negligence, breach of contract, breach of warranty, and slander of title.[2] 
Pursuant to section 29-5-10 of the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, the Burdges filed an offer of settlement in the amount of $10,000.[3]Â  In response, Southeastern offered to settle the case for $70,000.Â  Between the times these settlement offers were filed, the parties consented to have the case tried by the special referee.Â  
The special referee held a two-day hearing.Â  At the conclusion of Southeasternâ€™s case, the Burdges moved for a directed verdict as to the mechanicâ€™s lien action on the ground the requisite lis pendens had not been filed pursuant to section 29-5-120 of the South Carolina Code of Laws.[4] During the hearing and in a written order, the special referee granted the motion and dismissed the mechanicâ€™s lien action.Â  In so holding, the special referee found the Burdges were not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees and costs under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute given there was no effective mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  The special referee further reasoned that the lack of a lis pendens could have been discovered at the time the mechanicâ€™s lien was filed; thus, the Burdges waived their right to an award of attorneyâ€™s fees by waiting approximately three years before raising the issue.Â  The case proceeded on Southeasternâ€™s remaining breach of contract claim and the Burdgesâ€™ counterclaims.
Ultimately, the special referee entered judgment against the Burdges in the amount of $36,269.27.Â  This award was based on the outstanding balance of $53,239.27 owed to Southeastern, which was offset by the damages in the amount of $16,970 incurred by the Burdges due to Southeasternâ€™s delay in completing the construction project.Â  The special referee denied both partiesâ€™ motions for reconsideration. 
The Burdges only appeal the special refereeâ€™s denial of their motion for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to the mechanicâ€™s lien.
DISCUSSION
The Burdges argue the special referee erred in failing to award them attorneyâ€™s fees and costs after dismissing Southeasternâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  In support of this argument, the Burdges contend they:Â  1) were the prevailing party because the special referee granted their directed verdict motion; 2) did not waive their right to attorneyâ€™s fees and costs; and 3) were entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees and costs because, despite the absence of a lis pendens, they had to defend against the mechanicâ€™s lien which encumbered their property.Â  We agree.
An action to foreclose a mechanicâ€™s lien is a law case in South Carolina.Â  Adams v. B & D, Inc., 297 S.C. 416, 420, 377 S.E.2d 315, 317 (1989).Â  â€œIn an action at law, tried without a jury, the judgeâ€™s findings will not be disturbed unless they are without evidentiary support.â€ King v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 317 S.C. 385, 388, 453 S.E.2d 885, 888 (1995).Â  â€œHis findings are equivalent to those of a jury in an action at law.â€Â  Id. at 389, 453 S.E.2d at 888.Â  The determination regarding the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees that should be awarded under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge and his decision will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  D.A. Davis Constr. Co. v. Palmetto Props., Inc., 281 S.C. 415, 419, 315 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1984).
â€œSection 29-5-20(A) requires the court to award reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to the party defending against the mechanicâ€™s lien if the defending party â€˜prevailsâ€™ in the action.â€Â  Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc. v. Palmieri, 345 S.C. 550, 553-54, 548 S.E.2d 900, 902 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  To determine the â€œprevailing partyâ€ in a mechanicâ€™s lien action, this court has explained:

  In the context of statutes allowing attorney fees, our supreme court has defined a â€œprevailing partyâ€ as â€œ[t]he one who successfully prosecutes the action or successfully defends against it, prevailing on the main issue, even though not to the extent of the original contention [and] is the one in whose favor the decision or verdict is rendered and judgment entered.â€Â  Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 182-83, 394 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1990)(quoting Buza v. Columbia Lumber Co., 395 P.2d 511, 514 (Alaska 1964)).Â  Thus, the court of appeals concluded in a mechanicâ€™s lien foreclosure action the party in whose favor the decision or verdict on liability is rendered is the prevailing party for purposes of awarding attorney fees.Â  See Utilities Constr. Co. v. Wilson, 321 S.C. 244, 468 S.E.2d 1 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  According to Heath, â€œa party need not be successful as to all issues in order to be found a prevailing party.â€Â  Heath, 302 S.C. at 182, 394 S.E.2d at 711; see Utilities Constr. Co., 321 S.C. at 248-49, 468 S.E.2d at 3-4.
  Therefore, in a mechanicâ€™s lien action the defendant is entitled to an award of attorney fees as the prevailing party if it is determined that a mechanicâ€™s lien cannot be enforced against it.

Seckinger v. The Vessel, Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 388, 483 S.E.2d 775, 777 (Ct. App. 1997).Â Â  Additionally, this court has stated:

  A fair interpretation of the text of [section 29-5-10(a)] convinces us that it is the enforcement of the lien which confers the right to attorney fees, and not the joinder of an attempted enforcement with another non-statutory cause of action on which the lienor prevails.Â  In addition to affording an aggrieved mechanic a complete remedy for the collection of his debt, we recently held the Legislature also intended to afford a property owner a remedy where a mechanic attempts to enforce a defective or wrongful mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  

Utilities Constr. Co. v. Wilson, 321 S.C. 244, 247-48, 468 S.E.2d 1, 2-3 (Ct. App. 1996).
Turning to the instant case, we find, and the parties do not contest, the special referee properly directed a verdict in favor of Appellants on Southeasternâ€™s action to foreclose the mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Because Southeastern failed to file a notice of the pendency of the action, a statutory-prerequisite, the lien against the Appellantsâ€™ property was dissolved.Â  See Muller v. Myrtle Beach Golf & Yacht Club, 303 S.C. 137, 140-41, 399 S.E.2d 430, 432 (Ct. App. 1990), overruled on other grounds by Myrtle Beach Hosp, Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 341 S.C. 1, 532 S.E.2d 868 (2000) (â€œA mechanicâ€™s lien is purely statutory.Â  Therefore, the requirements of the statute must be strictly followed.Â  If anyone of these requirements is not met, the lien against the property is dissolved.â€) (citations omitted).Â  The question then becomes whether Appellants were entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.
Initially, we note the fact that Southeastern prevailed on its breach of contract action is not dispositive of the decision whether to award Appellants attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Instead, our focus is confined solely to the procedure outlined in the mechanicâ€™s lien statute and case law interpreting the statute.Â  
Given the special referee directed a verdict in favor of Appellants, he held as a matter of law, not based on a â€œmere technicality,â€ that Southeastern could not enforce its mechanicâ€™s lien against Appellants.Â  Based on this ruling, Appellants successfully defended against the lien and were, thus, the â€œprevailing partiesâ€ on the mechanicâ€™s lien cause of action.Â  See Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc., 345 S.C. at 554-55, 548 S.E.2d at 902-03 (finding Appellants were â€œprevailing partiesâ€ and, thus entitled to attorney fees pursuant to the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, where Appellants were dismissed as a party from the mechanicâ€™s lien foreclosure action based on a procedural rule and not a â€œmere technicalityâ€); Utilities Constr. Co., 321 S.C. at 247, 468 S.E.2d at 2 (holding property owner was â€œprevailing partyâ€ and entitled to attorney fees where trial court directed a verdict in favor of property owner on construction companyâ€™sÂ  mechanicâ€™s lien action on the ground company failed to timely serve notice of the mechanicâ€™s lien, even though jury returned a verdict in favor of construction company on remaining causes of action for breach of contract and unjust enrichment); Cedar Creek Props. v. Cantelou Assocs., 320 S.C. 483, 486, 465 S.E.2d 774, 775-76 (Ct. App. 1995) (ruling property company was the â€œprevailing partyâ€ under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute and, thus entitled to attorney fees, where contractor cancelled mechanicâ€™s lien prior to hearing on property companyâ€™s motion to determine the validity of mechanicâ€™s lien given that property company â€œstill had to defend against the lien until the issue was resolvedâ€ even though it â€œessentially got the relief it sought, that is, avoidance of the lienâ€).Â  
Accordingly, we find the special referee erred in denying Appellantsâ€™ request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Because there is no evidence in the record concerning the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees incurred by Appellants in defending against the mechanicâ€™s lien action, we remand to the special referee to determine this amount.Â  See Cedar Creek Props., 320 S.C. at 486-87, 465 S.E.2d at 776 (finding trial court, on remand, must award â€œprevailing partyâ€ under mechanicâ€™s lien statute an amount of attorneyâ€™s fees limited to those actions specifically involving the lien); cf. Utilities Constr. Co., 321 S.C. at 250, 468 S.E.2d at 4 (holding amount of attorneyâ€™s fees in mechanicâ€™s lien action was excessive where trial court awarded property owner attorneyâ€™s fees which included fees associated with the underlying contract cause of action; remanding to trial court to enter amount of attorneyâ€™s fees â€œbased upon time [property ownerâ€™s counsel] spent in defending the mechanicâ€™s lien cause of action onlyâ€). 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  In their Answer and Counterclaim, the Burdges also alleged causes of action against several third-party defendants, including subcontractors and the architectural firm.Â  These claims were settled and are not pertinent to the instant case.
[3]Â  Section 29-5-10(a) defines a mechanicâ€™s lien as follows:

  A person to whom a debt is due for labor performed or furnished or for materials furnished and actually used in the erection, alteration, or repair of a building or structure upon real estate or the boring and equipping of wells, by virtue of an agreement with, or by consent of, the owner of the building or structure, or a person having authority from, or rightfully acting for, the owner in procuring or furnishing the labor or materials shall have a lien upon the building or structure and upon the interest of the owner of the building or structure in the lot of land upon which it is situated to secure the payment of the debt due to him.Â  The costs which may arise in enforcing or defending against the lien under this chapter, including a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee, may be recovered by the prevailing party. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (Supp. 2004); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 29-5-10(b), 5-20(C) (Supp. 2004) (outlining procedure to determine â€œprevailing partyâ€ with respect to settlement offers); Seckinger v. The Vessel, Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 389, 483 S.E.2d 775, 778 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œSection 29-5-10(b) outlines a specific procedure which provides for formal offers of settlement, and modifies the common law definition of â€˜prevailing partyâ€™ to provide that the party whose offer is closer to the verdict reached is considered the prevailing party.â€).
[4]Â  Section 29-5-120 of the South Carolina Code of Laws provides, â€œUnless a suit for enforcing the lien is commenced, and notice of pendency of the action is filed, within six months after the person desiring to avail himself thereof ceases to labor on or furnish labor or material for such building or structures, the lien shall be dissolved.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-120 (1991); see Multiplex Bldg. Corp. v. Lyles, 268 S.C. 577, 580, 235 S.E.2d 133, 135 (1977) (holding that failure to file statutorily-required notice of pendency of mechanicâ€™s lien action mandated dismissal of action).

v.

  
    
      
        Raymond Hayes, III, Appellant.

James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-623
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 9, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; Solicitor Edgar L. Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Raymond Hayes, III, appeals his conviction of one count of possession of crack cocaine and one count of resisting arrest.Â  The trial court sentenced Hayes to six months for resisting arrest and five years and a $2500 fine for possession of crack cocaine suspended upon service of six months and two years probation, each sentence to be served concurrently.Â  Hayes alleges the trial court erred in admitting the crack-cocaine into evidence despite the Stateâ€™s failure to comply with Rule 6, SCRCrimP.Â  Counsel for Hayes attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Hayes did not file a separate pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Hayesâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.[1]
APPEAL DISMISSED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Unpublished Opinion No. 05-UP-624
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 9, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lagerald Feon Dunham appeals his convictions for possession of marijuana and possession of crack cocaine.Â  The trial court sentenced Dunham to one year for possession of marijuana and a concurrent term of ten years and a $10,000 fine for possession of crack-cocaine.Â  Moreover, the trial court revoked Dunhamâ€™s probationary sentence for assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature and reinstated his eight-year sentence on that conviction, to be served concurrently with the other sentences.Â  Dunham alleges the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  Counsel for Dunham attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Dunham filed a pro se brief contending that the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because of an allegedly defective indictment, and that the State failed to comply with Rule 6(a)(2), SCRCrimP.Â  
After a thorough review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Dunhamâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved.[1]
APPEAL DISMISSED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Eddie Oâ€™Neil Haney appeals his guilty plea and sentence for each of two counts of assault and battery with intent to kill and one count of first-degree burglary, all to run concurrently.Â  Haney argues the trial judge failed to adequately advise him of his constitutional rights so that he could waive those rights knowingly and intelligently.Â  Counsel for Haney attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Haney did not file a separate pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Haneyâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.[1]Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Mitchell Daniels, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 05-UP-626
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 9, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Mitchell Daniels appeals his conviction of and sentence for murder.Â  His counsel contends the trial court failed to adequately inform him of the constitutional rights he waived by entering a guilty plea.Â  Counsel for Daniels attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Daniels did not file a separate pro se response.
After a thorough review of the record as required by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Danielsâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.[1] 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

text:

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        David Mitchell Tucker, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-627
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 9, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of S.C. Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott all of Columbia, and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, David Mitchell Tucker, was indicted for and convicted of distribution of Oxycontin, a Schedule II controlled substance, and distribution of Lortab, a Schedule III controlled substance.Â  The trial judge sentenced Tucker to twelve years on each charge.Â  Tuckerâ€™s counsel attached to the brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating that he had reviewed the record and concluded this appeal lacks merit.Â  Tucker filed a separate pro se brief.Â  This court directed the parties to address the admissibility of evidence identifying the drugs predicated upon the stateâ€™s expertâ€™s reliance on the PDR, Physicians Desk Reference.Â  We now affirm1 pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 58-59, 609 S.E.2d 520, 523 (2005) (holding to preserve an issue for review there must be a contemporaneous objection that is ruled upon by the trial court; an objection should be addressed to the trial court in a sufficiently specific manner that brings attention to the exact error, and if a party fails to properly object, the party is procedurally barred from raising the issue on appeal); State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003) (noting â€œ[a] party need not use the exact name of a legal doctrine in order to preserve it, but it must be clear that the argument has been presented on that groundâ€); State v. Williams, 303 S.C. 410, 411, 401 S.E.2d 168, 169 (1991) (finding an appellate court will not consider issues that are not raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge, and a defendant must object at his first opportunity to preserve an issue for appellate review).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY,JJ., concur.

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Didato v. Palmetto Bay Owners Association
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Michael Roy Didato, Appellant,
v.
Palmetto Bay Owners Association, Inc.; Palmetto Bay Horizontal Property Regime; Gregory A. Wynn; and Eugene
Kransinki; Matt Bricker; Diane Peterkin; Nora Bess, and Jeremy White, Individually and as Directors of Palmetto Bay Horizontal Property Regime,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-630
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack D. Simrill, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
Bob J. Conley and Thomas J. Keaveny, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Michael Roy Didato brought suit against Respondents, alleging breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act and slander of title.Â  He appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Respondents, which found the claims were barred under the doctrine of accord and satisfaction.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
In April of 1999, Michael Roy Didato bought a condominium unit at the Palmetto Bay Horizontal Property Regime (Regime).Â  Shortly after moving in, Didato switched the door on the mechanical closet adjacent to his living room and balcony with his front door.Â  Didato vacated the unit in February of 2001 and gave control of the unit to his sister, Madelaine Arata, and his father, Roy Didato.Â  
Gregory A. Wynn, the Regime Manager, wrote Didato on March 21, 2001, and informed him that the door exchange was prohibited.Â  Wynn contended the mechanical closet door was a common element of the Regime and the doorâ€™s removal violated the by-laws of the Regime.Â  Wynn advised Didato to place the doors back in their original positions before March 31, 2001, or the Regime would have the door to the mechanical closet replaced at Didatoâ€™s expense.Â  Didato responded by letter dated March 27, 2001, refusing to replace the doors and threatening to call the police if the Regime attempted to gain access to his unit.Â  
On April 9, 2001, Anne C. Marscher, an attorney for the Regime, wrote Didato and requested he replace the mechanical closet door.Â  The letter informed Didato that a special assessment of $50 a day would be levied against him and constitute a lien on his property if Didato failed to comply.Â  After Didato decided to sell the unit, Arata and her husband made extensive repairs to the unit.Â  Didato claims Arata replaced the mechanical door as â€œone of the first tasks [she] attended to when [she] entered the unit on March 31, 2001.â€Â  The Regime contends it did not notice the doors had been replaced until May 31, 2001, and the Regime levied fines against the unit from May 10, 2001 until that date.Â  
On June 20, 2001, Didato signed a specific power of attorney making Arata his attorney-in-fact with respect to the sale of the unit.Â  On January 8, 2002, Marscher wrote Didato and demanded payment of $1,999.56 in fines and attorneysâ€™ fees arising from the door exchange.Â  The Regime filed a lien on Didatoâ€™s unit for that amount on January 9, 2002.Â  
Arata hired an attorney, H. Fred Kuhn, Jr., to get the lien removed.Â  On July 11, 2002, Marscher wrote Kuhn that â€œ[p]ursuant to [their] telephone conversation . . . Michael R. Didato will not be responsible for the $1,100 billed in fines.â€Â  The Regime executed a release and satisfaction of lien with respect to the unit on July 16, 2002.Â  Arata sold the unit on July 17, 2002 and paid the Regime the remainder of the amount owed.Â  Kuhn stated he was hired to remove the lien and agreed that â€œthe parties reached a resolution as to the lien.â€Â  Likewise, Arata agreed that the lien matter â€œwas resolved by [the] release and satisfaction of the lien.â€Â  
Almost a year later, Didato filed a complaint against the Regime for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act and slander of title.Â  The Regime answered, alleging various defenses, including accord and satisfaction.Â  The Regime made a motion for summary judgment, asserting Didatoâ€™s claims were barred under the doctrine of accord and satisfaction.[1]Â  The trial court granted the Regimeâ€™s motion.Â  Didato filed a motion to reconsider and amend judgment, which the trial court denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue of material fact such that the moving party must prevail as a matter of law.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences that may be drawn from the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  White v. J.M. Brown Amusement Co., Inc., 360 S.C. 366, 370-71, 601 S.E.2d 342, 344 (2004) (citations omitted). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Accord and Satisfaction
Didato asserts the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to the Regime finding Didatoâ€™s claims were barred by the doctrine of accord and satisfaction.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe elements of an accord and satisfaction are the agreement between the parties to settle a dispute (the accord), and the payment of the consideration expressed in the accord (the satisfaction).â€Â  Fanning v. Hicks, 284 S.C. 456, 458, 327 S.E.2d 342, 343 (1985).Â  
Didato initially argues that because his sister and Kuhn made an agreement with the Regime, the Regime is precluded from asserting accord and satisfaction against Didato personally, pursuant to Brazell Brothers Contractors v. Hill, 245 S.C. 69, 138 S.E.2d 835 (1964).Â  In Brazell Brothers, the insurer for the Brazells paid Hill $475.00 in satisfaction of Hillâ€™s claims against the Brazells arising from an automobile collision.Â  Id. at 72, 138 S.E.2d at 836.Â  When the Brazells asserted a claim against Hill arising from the same accident, Hill argued the agreement with the insurer constituted a compromise and settlement of all claims arising from the accident.Â  Id. at 72-73, 138 S.E.2d at 836.Â  Because South Carolina recognizes an automobile accident as creating two separate causes of action, the Supreme Court of South Carolina held â€œ[s]ince [the Brazellsâ€™] cause of action was separate and distinct from [Hillâ€™s cause of action], we perceive no legal impediment to settlement of it alone, leaving the Brazells untrammeled in the pursuit of their own claim, as to which the [insurance] carrier owed no responsibility and had no authority.â€Â  Id. at 74, 138 S.E.2d at 837 (emphasis added).Â  Unlike the insurance carrier in Brazell Brothers, Arata acted under a power of attorney giving her authority to â€œdo all lawful acts affecting the sale of real estate.â€Â  Arata had the authority to settle all claims arising out of the lien dispute.Â  According to the statements of Arata and Kuhn, Arata intended and agreed to finally settle this dispute.Â  Therefore, Didato is bound by this agreement.
Didato next argues the lien release evidences an intent to release only the claims the Regime had against Didato.Â  While the express language of the lien release indicates the Regime released all claims against Didato, it is evidence of the satisfaction, not the accord.Â  The lien release makes no mention of an agreement between Didato and the Regime.Â  In addition, it does not state what consideration for the release, if any, changed hands.Â  The agreement of the parties (the accord) occurred before the Release was executed, as evidenced by the letter from Marscher to Kuhn dated July 11, 2002.Â  The record shows only Arataâ€™s and Kuhnâ€™s statements to evidence an agreement between the parties.Â  Therefore, viewed in a light most favorable to Didato, the evidence shows the parties agreed to settle all claims arising from the lien dispute (the accord) and, in satisfaction, the Regime executed a lien release.Â Â Â Â  
Even if we found the lien release provided evidence of an intention to release only the Regimeâ€™s claims against Didato, we hold accord and satisfaction would still bar Didatoâ€™s suit.Â  â€œWhen the claims of the opposing parties are viewed as a single cause of action, it is plausible to import mutuality to any settlement between them, thus barring the right of either party to pursue the other, even though the release is, by its terms, unilateral.â€Â  Brazell Bros., 245 S.C. at 74, 138 S.E.2d at 837.Â  See also B&B Bail Bonds Agency of Connecticut Inc. v. Bailey, 770 A.2d 960, 963 (Conn. 2001) (â€œAlthough the case law presents the more usual use of accord and satisfaction as a defense by the debtor against the creditor, it is evident that accord and satisfaction equally applies to both parties.â€).Â  Having agreed to surrender $1,225.60 in settlement of the Regimeâ€™s claims against him, Didato cannot now argue those claims were fraudulent and deny that accord and satisfaction applies equally to bar his claims against the Regime.
II. The Mechanical Closet Door and the By-Laws
Didato argues a genuine issue of material fact exists as to whether the mechanical closet door is a common element of the Regime, and whether the exchange of the doors constituted a violation of the by-laws of the Regime.Â  These issues are not preserved for review.[2]Â  â€œIf the losing party has raised an issue in the lower court, but the court fails to rule upon it, the party must file a motion to alter or amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appellate review.â€Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000).Â  The trial court in this case granted summary judgment solely on the grounds that Didatoâ€™s claims were barred by accord and satisfaction.Â  Although Didato made a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend, he merely asked the trial court to make a ruling on accord and satisfaction and neglected to ask for a ruling on whether the doors were a common element or whether exchanging the doors violated the Regime bylaws.Â  Therefore, Didato has not properly preserved these issues for appeal.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the trial courtâ€™s decision is
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Although the Regime originally moved for summary judgment on two grounds, its memorandum in support of summary judgment asked for relief based only on accord and satisfaction.Â  
[2] Didato argues in his memorandum in opposition to summary judgment that the issue of whether Didato â€œexercised ownership over limited common elementsâ€ by switching the doors and whether â€œthis constituted a violation of the Master Deed and By-Laws of the Regimeâ€ affects a determination of accord and satisfaction.Â  To the extent Didatoâ€™s brief can be read to reassert this position, we disagree and find that whether the mechanical closet door is a limited common element and whether Didatoâ€™s actions violated the by-laws of the Regime have no bearing on whether the parties agreed to settle the lien dispute.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

v.

William Thomas Moody, of York and Robert W. McCleave,of Rock Hill, for Appellants.
David E. Simpson, of York, for Respondent.
Leah Moody, of Rock Hill, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal arises from the termination of the parental rights of Lisa Deweese and Eugene Howell.Â  The court found Deweeseâ€™s parental rights, as to Austin Webb and Aimee Howell, should be terminated on four grounds: 1) the children have been out of the home for a period of six months and Deweese has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal; 2) a willful failure to provide support; 3) Deweese has a diagnosable condition of drug and alcohol addiction that is unlikely to change within a reasonable time; and 4) the children have been in DSSâ€™ custody for fifteen of twenty-two months.Â  The court found Howellâ€™s parental rights, as to Aimee Howell, should be terminated on five grounds: 1) the child has been out of the home for a period of six months and Howell has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal; 2) a willful failure to provide support; 3) a willful failure to visit; 4) Howell has a diagnosable condition of drug and alcohol addiction that is unlikely to change within a reasonable time; and 5) the child has been in DSSâ€™ custody for fifteen of twenty-two months.Â  Additionally, the court found termination was in the best interest of the child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2004).
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), we affirm[1] the family courtâ€™s ruling and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal arises from a contested Permanency Planning Hearing.Â  The South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) sought, inter alia, to retain custody of Frederick (Downer) and Melissa Downerâ€™s child Frederica, to enjoin Downer from having contact with the other eight children who remain in Melissaâ€™s custody, and to have Downer pay child support to Melissa.Â  The family court found Downer failed to complete the prescribed treatment plan, and having Downer pay child support would be in the childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  The family court also found Fredericaâ€™s best interest would be served by DSS retaining custody, because she would be eighteen in three months and was doing well.Â  Accordingly, the family court adopted the Permanency Plan with the proviso Downer begin paying child support within fourteen days of his release from prison. text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

v.

Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant. 
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael Cunningham was convicted of first-degree burglary and sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  Cunningham appeals, contending the trial court erred in refusing to grant a mistrial after a police officer volunteered allegedly inadmissible material in response to cross-examination by defense counsel.Â  Although we find the officerâ€™s comments clearly improper, we find the error harmless.Â  We affirm. 
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We disagree with the trial courtâ€™s ruling to the extent that it could be viewed as condoning the policeâ€™s officerâ€™s remark on cross-examination.Â  Cunningham did not present a case, and never put his character at issue so as to â€œopen the doorâ€ for purposes of Rule 404(a)(1), SCRE.Â  Furthermore, we find the officerâ€™s gratuitous statement not responsive to the question, which called for only a â€œyesâ€ or â€œnoâ€ answer.Â  
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Due to the overwhelming evidence of guilt in this case, however, we do not find reversible error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Cunninghamâ€™s motion for a mistrial pursuant to the following authorities:Â  State v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 33-34, 615 S.E.2d 455, 460 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding that a grant of a mistrial is a drastic action that should be exercised only when no other curative action could remove the prejudice claimed);Â  State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 409, 613 S.E.2d 760, 784 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œError is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€).Â Â  
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
