title: State v. Logan
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
James Leroy Logan, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion 2005-UP-639
Heard October 6, 2005 â€“ Filed December 15, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Samuel Christopher Bauer, of Hilton Head Island; Scott M. Merrifield, of Beaufort; for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, III, of Hampton; for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  James Leroy Logan, Jr., appeals his conviction in magistrateâ€™s court for driving under the influence of alcohol (DUI), first offense.Â  He contends the circuit court erred in failing to reverse the decision of the magistrate denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
At approximately 2:25 a.m. on October 7, 2002, South Carolina Highway Patrolman R. J. Gannon was dispatched to the scene of a single-vehicle accident at Sea Pines Circle on Hilton Head Island.Â  When he arrived, Gannon observed a vehicle â€œat a forty-five degree angle lodged in a tree.â€Â  As Gannon approached the vehicle, he noticed that another patrolman had broken out the rear passenger window and was trying to assist Logan, who was in the vehicle, until he could receive medical attention.Â  Gannon noticed â€œa very strong smell of alcoholic beverage coming from the passenger car within the vehicle.â€Â  
Once the EMS stabilized Logan, they placed him in an ambulance.Â  At that point, Gannon asked Logan for some personal information and requested his driverâ€™s license.Â  Gannon claimed that â€œ[w]hile talking with Mr. Logan, the smell of alcoholic beverage was even strongerâ€ than when he spoke with Logan in the vehicle.Â  As a result, Gannon advised Logan of his Miranda[1] rights.Â  In response to Gannonâ€™s questions, Logan told Gannon that he was on vacation, he had been â€œout on the town for the night,â€ and had been to a couple of local clubs.Â  Logan, however, could not identify the names of the clubs.Â  Because he believed Logan had been driving under the influence, Gannon requested a blood sample and informed Logan of his implied consent rights.Â  According to Gannon, Logan was unable to sign the implied consent form due to his injuries.Â  Logan declined to submit to a blood test.Â  Gannon further testified that Loganâ€™s physical condition prevented EMS from transporting him to a breathalyzer test site.Â  
At the hospital, Gannon served Logan with a notice of suspension and asked him again about the accident.Â  Logan only informed Gannon that he was not wearing his seatbelt at the time of the accident.Â  As a result, Gannon issued Logan a ticket for DUI and for a seatbelt violation.Â  On the ticket for DUI, Gannon noted in the â€œB.A. Levelâ€ box that Logan had refused this test.Â  
On October 22, 2003, a Beaufort County magistrate tried Loganâ€™s case.Â  After Gannon testified, Loganâ€™s counsel moved for a directed verdict for the DUI charge based on two primary grounds:Â  (1) there was no direct evidence that Logan was driving the vehicle at the time of the accident; and (2) there was no testimony regarding Loganâ€™s alleged impairment other than the fact that an accident had occurred and Gannon observed â€œan odor of alcoholic beverage.â€Â  The magistrate denied this motion as well as Loganâ€™s renewal of the motion after the defense rested its case without presenting testimony.
In a written order, the magistrate found Logan guilty of DUI and failure to wear a seatbelt.Â  He ordered Logan to pay a fine of $748 for DUI and $35 for the seatbelt violation.Â  In reaching his decision as to the DUI charge, the magistrate found:Â  (1) there was direct evidence that Logan was driving the vehicle at the time of the accident given he was still in the driverâ€™s seat at the time the officers arrived at the scene; and (2) Logan was driving under the influence of alcohol to the extent that his driving was impaired based on Gannonâ€™s testimony that Logan â€œsmelled of an alcoholic beverageâ€ and Logan told him that he had been to a couple of clubs prior to the accident.
Logan appealed his conviction for DUI to the circuit court.[2]Â  In his notice of appeal, Logan argued the magistrate erred in declining to direct a verdict because there was no evidence that Logan was driving the vehicle at the time of the accident or that his driving was impaired.
By order dated November 16, 2004, the circuit court affirmed the magistrateâ€™s decision.Â  Logan appeals.
DISCUSSION
Logan argues the circuit court erred in failing to reverse his DUI conviction.Â  Specifically, he contends the State failed to provide sufficient evidence that:Â  (1) he operated the vehicle involved in the accident; and (2) he was under the influence of alcohol while driving.Â  As a result, Logan asserts the magistrate should have granted his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We disagree.
An appellate court may reverse a trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict only if there is no evidence to support the courtâ€™s ruling.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002). Â â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.â€Â  State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 171 (2003).Â  A trial court should deny a motion for directed verdict if there is any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence that reasonably tends to prove an accusedâ€™s guilt, or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 563, 598 S.E.2d 279, 284 (Ct. App. 2004).
â€œBefore a defendant in a criminal case can be required to present a defense, the State must present some proof of the corpus delicti of the crime.Â  That is, the prosecution must show the actual commission by someone of the particular offense charged.â€Â  State v. Smith, 328 S.C. 622, 624-25, 493 S.E.2d 506, 508 (Ct. App. 1997) (citations omitted).Â Â Â  
â€œThe corpus delicti of DUI based upon alcohol is:Â  (1) driving a motor vehicle; (2) within this state; (3) while under the influence of alcohol to the extent that the personâ€™s faculties to drive are materially and appreciably impaired.â€Â  State v. Russell, 345 S.C. 128, 134, 546 S.E.2d 202, 205 (Ct. App. 2001); see State v. Salisbury, 343 S.C. 520, 524, 541 S.E.2d 247, 249 (2001) (stating â€œthe corpus delicti of DUI must be established by proof that a personâ€™s ability to drive has been materially and appreciably impaired by the use of alcohol and/or drugsâ€); see also State v. Sheppard, 248 S.C. 464, 466, 150 S.E.2d 916, 917 (1966) (â€œThe act of operating a motor vehicle with impaired faculties is the gravamenâ€ of a DUI offense.).[3]Â  â€œAll that the first element requires is that the State sufficiently prove that someone drove the automobile.â€Â  City of Easley v. Portman, 327 S.C. 593, 596, 490 S.E.2d 613, 615 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œâ€˜Under the influenceâ€™ means sufficiently under the influence as to impair the ability of such driver to operate the vehicle with reasonable care.â€Â  State v. Kerr, 330 S.C. 132, 143, 498 S.E.2d 212, 217 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œThe question is not whether the defendant is drunk or intoxicated, but whether his condition is such that he could drive with due regard for others and himself.â€Â  Id. at 144, 498 S.E.2d at 217-18.
â€œProof of the corpus delicti does not have to be in the form of direct evidence; it may be established by circumstantial evidence when it is the best evidence obtainable.â€ State v. Osborne, 335 S.C. 172, 180, 516 S.E.2d 201, 205 (1999); State v. Townsend, 321 S.C. 55, 57, 467 S.E.2d 138, 140 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œWhile evidence of the corpus delicti in a particular case must be established by the best proof attainable, direct evidence is not essential.Â  The corpus delicti may be sufficiently proved by presumptive or circumstantial evidence when that is the best obtainable.â€)(citations omitted).
Turning to the instant case, we find the State presented sufficient circumstantial evidence to establish the corpus delicti of the crime of DUI.Â  Officer Gannon found an injured Logan inside a vehicle that had just been involved in a single-vehicle accident.Â  No one else was present in the vehicle.Â  Gannon, who had been trained as an accident reconstructionist, opined that Logan â€œentered the traffic circle he went straight towards the embankment, up the embankment and on a tree and he came to rest on a tree.â€Â  Gannon believed the vehicle went airborne â€œa good six, seven feetâ€ before it collided with the tree.Â  He noted on the DUI traffic ticket that the weather was â€œclearâ€ at the time of the accident.Â  Eyewitnesses to the accident were unavailable at the time of trial.Â  However, Gannon testified without objection that Logan had been driving the vehicle. [4] Â  Furthermore, Gannon stated there was â€œa very strong smell of alcoholic beverageâ€ in the vehicle and an â€œeven strongerâ€ smell when he spoke directly to Logan.Â  Logan also told Gannon that he had been â€œout on the town for the nightâ€[5] and had been to a couple of local clubs.Â  In its order, the circuit court stated that Logan â€œadmitted that he had been â€˜out on the townâ€™ at establishments that served alcoholic beverages.â€ [6] Â  Loganâ€™s inability to recall the names of the clubs gave rise to the inference that Logan was intoxicated.Â  Logan also refused to submit to a blood test.Â  Although Gannon was unable, due to Loganâ€™s physical condition, to utilize field sobriety tests or a breathalyzer test, he believed Logan had been driving under the influence.Â  
Based on the foregoing, we hold the magistrate properly denied Loganâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  See Portman, 327 S.C. at 596, 490 S.E.2d at 615 (finding the following constituted sufficient evidence to establish the corpus delicti of the offense of DUI:Â  â€œthe Bronco had left the road; it rested up against a tree; the manner in which the Bronco had left the road indicated the driverâ€™s operation of the vehicle had been somehow impaired; Portman rested his head against the vehicle; he smelled of alcohol; he slurred his speech, a characteristic associated with one who is intoxicated; and the investigating officer believed Portman was under the influence of alcoholâ€); see also State v. Gilliam, 270 S.C. 345, 347, 242 S.E.2d 410, 411 (1978) (holding magistrate properly denied defendantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the charge of DUI where operator of a tow truck found defendant alone on the passenger side of a wrecked automobile, the accident had occurred approximately fifteen minutes prior to the tow truck operatorâ€™s arrival, the operator testified defendant smelled of alcohol and appeared to be under the influence, there was testimony that defendant was â€œramblingâ€ when questioned at the hospital where he received treatment, defendant admitted he had been driving at the time of the accident, and an open container of alcohol was found in the automobile); State v. McCombs, 335 S.C. 123, 127, 515 S.E.2d 547, 549 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding trial court properly denied defendantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the charge of DUI where officer discovered defendant at the scene of an automobile accident in an apparent intoxicated state, defendant smelled of alcohol and failed his breathalyzer, and officer believed defendant was impaired even though officer could not safely conduct field sobriety tests).
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision affirming Loganâ€™s magistrate court conviction for DUI is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, J., concurs, and SHORT, J., dissents in a separate opinion.
SHORT, J., dissenting in part:Â  After a careful analysis of the facts in this case, I conclude there was no evidence presented that reasonably tends to prove Logan was under the influence of alcohol to an extent that his ability to drive was materially and appreciably impaired; therefore, I must respectfully dissent.Â  
In reviewing a trial courtâ€™s denial of a criminal defendantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict, the appellate court must view the record in the light most favorable to the State and remember the granting or denial of a motion for a directed verdict turns on the existence of evidence not its weight.Â  State v. Brown, 267 S.C. 311, 316, 227 S.E.2d 674, 677 (1976).Â  A motion for a directed verdict should be denied â€œif there is any evidence, either direct or circumstantial, which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.â€Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â  
It is unlawful, in South Carolina, for a person to drive a motor vehicle if he is under the influence of alcohol to an extent that his ability â€œto drive is materially and appreciably impaired.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2930 (1) (Supp. 2004).Â  The cases cited by the majority all contain traditional indicia of material and appreciable impairment due to the consumption of alcohol.Â  Due to the absence of such evidence in the case at bar, it should be distinguished and Loganâ€™s motion for a directed verdict should have been granted.Â Â Â  
The first case cited by the majority in support of the magistrateâ€™s denial of Loganâ€™s motion for a directed verdict is City of Easley v. Portman, 327 S.C. 593, 490 S.E.2d 613 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The Portman case, unlike the case at bar, involved an extrajudicial confession and centered on corpus delicti.Â  Id. at 595, 490 S.E.2d at 614.Â  Therefore, while Portman may be enlightening, it does not control the case sub judice.Â  In Portman, we found the following was sufficient evidence to establish the corpus delicti of the offense of DUI: â€œthe Bronco had left the road; it rested up against a tree; the manner in which the Bronco had left the road indicated the driverâ€™s operation had some how been impaired; Portman rested his head against the vehicle; he smelled of alcohol; he slurred his speech, a characteristic associated with one who is intoxicated; and the investigating officer believed Portman was under the influence of alcohol.â€Â  Id. at 596-97, 490 S.E.2d at 615.Â  At the scene of the wreck, Portman stated, â€œI was driving the vehicle. Â Iâ€™m drunk, take me to jail.â€Â  Id. at 595, 490 S.E.2d at 614.Â  
The majority also discusses State v. Gilliam, 270 S.C. 345, 242 S.E.2d 410 (1978).Â  In Gilliam, our supreme court held that the defendantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict had been properly denied where a tow truck driver found the defendant alone in a car that had been in a single car accident fifteen minutes earlier; the tow truck driver testified that the defendant smelled like alcohol and appeared to be under the influence; the defendant was rambling at the hospital while receiving treatment; the defendant admitted he had been driving at the time of the accident; and an open container of alcohol was found in the car.Â  Id. at 347, 242 S.E.2d at 411.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
The final case cited by the majority is State v. McCombs, 335 S.C. 123, 515 S.E.2d 547 (Ct. App. 1999). Â In McCombs, we held that the defendantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict had been properly denied where an officer arrived on the scene of a car crash; knew and recognized the defendant as the owner of the vehicle; concluded the defendant had been the driver; testified that the defendant had bloodshot eyes, slurred speech, and smelled of alcohol, and based on these observations, the officer believed the defendant was under the influence; the defendant admitted that he was the driver of the vehicle and had been drinking; and the defendantâ€™s subsequent breathalyzer test reflected a blood-alcohol level of .16 percent. Â Id. at 126, 515 S.E.2d at 548.Â Â  
Like the defendants in the cases cited by the majority, Logan was involved in a car crash and smelled of alcohol.Â  However, the records in the other cases contained evidence showing traditional indicia of material and appreciable impairment due to the consumption of alcohol such as slurred speech, bloodshot eyes, rambling, testimony that the defendant appeared to be under the influence of alcohol, or an excessive blood-alcohol level.Â  There was no evidence presented at Loganâ€™s trial to show that he was materially and appreciably impaired due to the consumption of alcohol.Â  Officer Gannon testified that Logan drove straight through a traffic circle, his car left the road and hit a tree, he smelled like alcohol, he had been out to a few local clubs but could not recall their names, and that he refused a blood test.Â  He did not provide any testimony that the appellant was unsteady on his feet, slurred his speech, or was incoherent or otherwise possessed any of the generally accepted visible characteristics often associated with persons who are under the influence of alcohol.Â  
Automobile accidents happen for many different reasons, and often occur even when drivers are not impaired.Â  I am not persuaded that there is a link between a personâ€™s inability to remember the names of clubs and the consumption of alcohol, especially when the person is not from the area.Â  A refusal to submit to a blood test and the odor of alcohol may be evidence from which it can be inferred that a person has been drinking alcoholic beverages, but alone does not show material and appreciable impairment.Â Â Â  
An automobile wreck accompanied only by the smell of alcohol, a refusal of a blood test, and the driverâ€™s inability to remember the names of clubs that he had visited is not evidence from which material and appreciable impairment may fairly and logically be deduced.Â  See Brown, 267 S.C. at 316, 227 S.E.2d at 677 (a defendantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict should be granted if the evidence presented merely raises a suspicion of guilt).Â  Â Therefore, the state failed to present any evidence showing material and appreciable impairment, and Loganâ€™s motion for a directed verdict should have been granted.

[1]Â  Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).
[2]Â Â  Logan did not appeal his conviction for violating the seatbelt law.
[3]Â Â  Section 56-5-2930 of the South Carolina Code of Laws outlines the offense of DUI as follows:

It is unlawful for a person to drive a motor vehicle within this State while:
(1) under the influence of alcohol to the extent that the personâ€™s faculties to drive are materially and appreciably impaired;
(2) under the influence of any other drug or a combination of other drugs or substances which cause impairment to the extent that the personâ€™s faculties to drive are materially and appreciably impaired; or
(3) under the combined influence of alcohol and any other drug or drugs or substances which cause impairment to the extent that the personâ€™s faculties to drive are materially and appreciably impaired.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2930 (Supp. 2004).
[4]Â Â  Although we recognize that Loganâ€™s counsel objected at other points during Gannonâ€™s testimony regarding whether Logan was driving, there was one instance where he did not raise an objection.Â  Thus, we may take this testimony into consideration in reaching our decision.
[5]Â Â  â€œOut on the townâ€ has been explained to mean:Â  â€œWhen you go out partying and having fun at public places like bars, restaurants, and theatres, you are â€˜out on the town.â€™â€Â  This definition may be found at www.GoEnglish.com.
[6]Â Â Â Â  Logan did not challenge this finding.Â  Thus, it is the law of the case. See In re:Â  Morrison, 321 S.C. 370, 371, 468 S.E.2d 651, 653 (1996) (stating an unappealed ruling is the law of the case); Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 59, 552 S.E.2d 329, 334 (Ct. App. 2001) (noting unappealed finding is the law of the case).

title: State v. Workman
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
v.
William D. Workman, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-640
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 15, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Douglas Wannemacher, an officer of the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department, was on patrol in a marked car when he encountered appellant William Workman in the parking lot of an Economy Inn.Â  Workman had a strong alcoholic odor about his person and breath, and his eyes were glassy and bloodshot.Â  Wannemacher asked Workman where he was coming from.Â  Workman responded in a loud and slurred manner: â€œI just got off.Â  Why the f**k are you harassing me?Â  I know Iâ€™m black.â€Â  
Wannemacher arrested Workman for public disorderly conduct because Workman was grossly intoxicated in a public place and loudly using profanity.Â  Wannemacher observed Workman spit out what turned out to be cocaine and crack cocaine in the parking lot of the Greenville County Detention Center.Â  Workman argues the trial court erred by denying his motion to suppress this evidence, allegedly obtained in violation of the Fourth Amendment.Â  
Affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: Â State v. Missouri, 361 S.C. 107, 603 S.E.2d 594  (2004) (stating an appellate court must affirm the trial judgeâ€™s ruling if there is any evidence to support the ruling when reviewing a Fourth Amendment search and seizure case; the appellate court will reverse only when there is clear error);
State v. Burton, 326 S.C. 605, 486 S.E.2d 762 (Ct. App. 1997) (noting an in limine ruling is not final and does not preserve the issue for appeal); State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001) (stating a motion in limine to exclude evidence at the beginning of trial does not preserve an issue for review because a motion in limine is not a final determination; the moving party must make a contemporaneous objection when the evidence is introduced unless the ruling was immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence in question); State v. Floyd, 295 S.C. 518, 369 S.E.2d 842 (1988) (holding a ruling on a motion in limine remains subject to change based upon developments during trial).
AFFIRMED.[1]
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Robinson v. Robinson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Theodore Thomas Robinson, Appellant,
v.
Christina Margaret Robinson, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Jack Alan Landis, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-641
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed December 15, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas M. Neal, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Donald Bruce Clark, of Charleston, Emily G. Johnston, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Theodore Thomas Robinson (â€œHusbandâ€) appeals a family court order distributing marital property between he and his former wife, Christina Margaret Robinson (â€œWifeâ€).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1996, Husband and Wife married in Nantucket, Massachusetts.Â  Following their marriage, Husband moved in with Wife and her three children into a Massachusetts home owned by Wife (hereinafter â€œthe Homeâ€).[2]Â  During the marriage, Wife granted Husband a one-half interest in the Home through a quitclaim deed, though she claims Husband somewhat tricked her into doing so.Â  Over the course of the marriage, Husband performed a substantial amount of work improving the Home, including masonry repair, rewiring, installing shelving units, and replacing the kitchenâ€™s sub-floor.Â  Husband claims he also paid the mortgage payments on the Home, which included the payments on a homeownerâ€™s insurance policy.Â  Wife, the sole owner of the insurance policy, claims she gave Husband monthly income she received from a prior spouse for child support to make the mortgage payments.Â  It is uncontested that the mortgage and insurance premiums were paid with marital funds.
In January 2002, the Home was completely destroyed by fire.Â  Pursuant to the insurance policy, Wife received $17,850 for rental payments, $103,177 to replace personal property, and $199,125 to rebuild the Home.Â  Following the fire, the couple decided to relocate and get â€œa fresh startâ€ on their lives and marriage.Â  Husband sold his cleaning business for $17,000.Â  Using the insurance proceeds and funds from the sale of Husbandâ€™s business, the couple made a down payment on a home in James Island, South Carolina.Â  In order to secure financing for the new home, a large amount of Husbandâ€™s credit card debt was paid off with insurance proceeds.Â  The couple also used the policyâ€™s proceeds to replace most of the familyâ€™s personal possessions destroyed by the fire.Â  In August 2002, Husband, Wife, and Wifeâ€™s two remaining dependent children moved into the South Carolina home.Â  That same month, the couple began rebuilding the Massachusetts home.Â  The rebuilding of the Home was funded entirely with Wifeâ€™s insurance proceeds, but Husband claims he contributed significantly to the organization of the rebuilding efforts.
In the months following their move to South Carolina, the coupleâ€™s relationship broke down.Â  Once in South Carolina, both parties worked only sporadically.Â  Husband claims Wife was drinking too much and acting erratically.Â  Although he concedes he lacks proof of unfaithfulness and did not assert adultery as a ground for divorce, Husband maintains the belief that Wife was having extramarital affairs with a church deacon and others during this time period.Â  Wife cites Husbandâ€™s baseless paranoia and wild accusations of infidelity as the leading cause of their marital difficulties.Â  
On March 1, 2003, Husband left the marital home and eventually moved back to Massachusetts.Â  Before leaving, Husband took Wifeâ€™s name off a joint banking account containing approximately $14,000 of Wifeâ€™s insurance proceeds.Â  He claims he spent a large portion of this money on family debts.Â  Nevertheless, Wife was left with only her monthly child support payments and three personal checks Husband left behind for her to buy groceries.Â  Husband later stopped payment on these checks.Â  On March 11, 2003, only days after leaving the marital home, Husband filed the present action for separate support and maintenance.Â  On this date, the rebuilding of the Massachusetts home had only progressed to the point of laying the foundation.
The rebuilding of the Massachusetts home was completed on December 12, 2003.Â  Shortly thereafter, the new residence sold for $365,000, resulting in a net profit of $251,499.Â  Due to the pending case, the parties agreed to disburse $40,000 of the profits equally between them (as an advance against any future award of equitable distribution) and place the remaining $211,499 in escrow until the pending resolution of this case.Â  
Following a two-day trial on Husbandâ€™s action for separate support and maintenance, the family court entered a final order on April 22, 2004, distributing the marital property.Â  In regard to the Massachusetts home and the proceeds from its sale, the family court concluded that the asset was transmuted into marital property due to the joint title and Husbandâ€™s substantial improvements on the original home.Â  In dividing this asset, however, the court awarded Husband only twenty-five percent of the proceeds from the homeâ€™s sale.Â  Defending this division, the family court explained, â€œas a result of the wifeâ€™s prior ownership of the home, prior ownership of the insurance policy and the wifeâ€™s purchase of the home out of foreclosure, [Wife earned a] special equity that warrants wife receiving a greater percentage of the value of the marital residence.â€Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We remain mindful that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
DISCUSSION
I. The Massachusetts Residence
Husband contends the family court erred in awarding him only a twenty-five percent share of the proceeds from the sale of the Massachusetts residence.Â  We disagree.
The family court determined that the newly rebuilt Massachusetts home, although owned by Wife prior to the marriage, was transmuted into a marital asset.Â  See Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 295, 372 S.E.2d 107, 110 (Ct. App. 1988) (holding nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital property if:Â  (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable;Â  (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property).Â  This ruling of the family court was not appealed and is therefore the law of the case.Â  See Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 632, 576 S.E.2d 156, 166 (2003).Â Â  The conclusion that the proceeds from the Homeâ€™s sale are marital property, however, does not necessarily dictate an even division of the funds.
All marital property, upon dissolution of a marriage, should be divided and distributed in a manner that fairly reflects each spouseâ€™s contribution to its acquisition, preservation, and change in value.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(3) (Supp. 2004); Johnson, 296 S.C. at 293, 372 S.E.2d at 109.Â  In determining an equitable division of marital property, the family court must consider the factors set forth in South Carolina Code Section 20-7-472 (Supp. 2004), giving each factor the weight the court deems appropriate.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  This court will affirm the family court judge if it can be determined that the judge addressed the statutory factors sufficiently for us to conclude he was cognizant of them. Id.Â  
In the present case, the family court specifically addressed in considerable detail each of the equitable apportionment statuteâ€™s fifteen enumerated factors.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2004).Â  The court determined the large profits received from the Homeâ€™s sale were largely â€œdue to the location of the home, the neighborhood it was in, and the fact that [Wife] purchased it years ago.â€Â  The court concluded Wifeâ€™s prior ownership of the home and insurance policy and her purchase of the home out of foreclosure entitled her to a larger share of the proceeds from its sale.Â  Since a spouseâ€™s contribution to acquiring a marital asset is one of the statutory factors, the family court acted within its discretion in heavily weighing Wifeâ€™s acquisition of the Home and insurance policy.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(3) (Supp. 2004).Â  Furthermore, our own review of the record leads us to conclude Husband was generously compensated for his direct and indirect contributions to the marital residence with a twenty-five percent portion of the net sales proceeds.Â  See Johnson, 296 S.C. at 300, 372 S.E.2d at 113 (â€œ[T]his Court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment.Â  If the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that this court might have weighed specific factors differently than the trial judge.â€).Â  Because the family court addressed each of the statutory factors for equitable distribution, we affirm the family courtâ€™s division of this marital asset.[3]Â  See Jenkins, 345 S.C. at 100, 545 S.E.2d at 537.
II. Debt Owed To Husbandâ€™s Father
Husband contends the family court erred in not apportioning a debt owed to his father.Â  Specifically, he argues the couple owes his father interest payments on money that was borrowed, placed in escrow, but paid back to his father without being spent.Â  This issue is not properly preserved for our review.
Although Husband listed the debt owed to his father in his financial declaration and vaguely referenced the loanâ€™s interest at the hearing, the family courtâ€™s order merely addresses the debt as it applies to the propertyâ€™s transmutation and does not rule upon the issue of apportioning the debt between the parties.Â  Because the family court did not specifically rule on this issue and Husband filed no Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the courtâ€™s order, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 118-19, 557 S.E.2d 693, 704-05 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding an issue must be ruled upon by the family court or raised in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to be preserved for appellate review).
III. Funds From Joint Bank Account
Husband argues the family court erred in crediting him the $7,000 he took from the coupleâ€™s joint bank account prior to leaving the marital home because the funds were spent on marital obligations.Â  We disagree.
Although the family court order acknowledges Husband took $7,000 from the account, we find no reference to the funds in question in the apportionment of personal property and debt.Â  As such, we fail to see how Husband was actually credited this amount.Â  Furthermore, the issue of whether these funds were properly apportioned by the family court should have been raised in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to be preserved for our review.Â  Id.Â  Raising the issue in a post-trial motion would have clarified the family courtâ€™s order, eradicating Husbandâ€™s need to speculate on appeal as to the family courtâ€™s treatment of these marital funds.
IV. Husbandâ€™s Life Insurance
Husband contends the family court erred in crediting him, for the purposes of equitable distribution, with the $3,249 cash value of his life insurance policy.Â  We disagree.
Marital property is generally defined as all real and personal property acquired by the parties during the marriage.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  Accordingly, any active increase in the cash value of a life insurance policy over the course of a marriage is marital property.Â  Husbandâ€™s life insurance policy was valued at approximately $3,000 when the parties married.Â  Husband, however, cashed out the policy during the marriage, rendering the policyâ€™s cash value as zero.Â  At the present litigationâ€™s time of filing, the policyâ€™s value had been built back to $3,249.Â  Because this increase in the policyâ€™s value was effectuated with marital funds over the course of the marriage, the family court properly included the asset as part of the marital estate.
V. Credibility of the Parties and the Breakup of the Marriage
In a vague argument which does not request the reversal of any particular aspect of the family courtâ€™s order, Husband argues the family court erred in finding Wifeâ€™s testimony regarding the breakup of the marriage credible, while concluding that his testimony on the subject lacked credibility.Â  Concomitantly, he argues the family court erred in concluding Husband was largely to blame for their matrimonial failings.Â  Supporting his contentions, Husband devotes much of his brief to some minor inconsistencies and sporadic equivocal episodes in Wifeâ€™s testimony.Â  Although we review the facts of this case in accordance with our own view of the evidence, our deference to the family court judge regarding issues of credibility is well established.Â  See Bowers, 349 S.C. at 91, 561 S.E.2d at 613.Â Â Â  Due to the inconsequential nature of the faults in Wifeâ€™s testimony and the fact that the family court judge was in a better position to evaluate witness credibility, we affirm this aspect of the family courtâ€™s order.
VI. Marital Counseling
Husband argues the family court erred in failing to admit Wifeâ€™s testimony concerning marital counseling the couple received in Massachusetts.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review.
Prior to trial, Husband requested that Wife willingly release records from marriage counseling the couple received in Massachusetts.Â  Wife refused to sign the release.Â  At the hearing, Husbandâ€™s attorney sought to admit both his letter requesting the release and a letter from a church counselor in Massachusetts.Â  Wifeâ€™s counselâ€™s objection to the admission of these letters was sustained and the letters were proffered into evidence.Â  Husband now argues the family court erred in not admitting Wifeâ€™s testimony regarding the counseling.Â  The questions regarding the counseling, however, ceased upon the courtâ€™s refusal to admit the letter and Wife was never further questioned on the subject.Â  Not only was no objection made addressing Wifeâ€™s possible testimony, Husbandâ€™s attorney never even posed the initial queries into the subject.Â  This issue, therefore, is not preserved for our review.Â  See Widman, 348 S.C. at 118-19, 557 S.E.2d at 704-05 (holding an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the family court or raised in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to be preserved for appellate review).
VII. The Family Computer and Major Appliances
Husband also argues the family court erred in failing to credit Wife the value of the major appliances and the computer in the Charleston home.Â  Again, this aspect of the family courtâ€™s final order was not raised to the court in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion and, thus, is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Id.
VIII. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband argues the family court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife and, conversely, in failing to award attorneyâ€™s fees to him, because he was, in fact, the prevailing party of the litigation.Â  We disagree.Â  
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. See Bowen v. Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 563, 490 S.E.2d 271, 272 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on the partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992). 
In the present case, the family court expressly considered each of these factors in considerable detail.Â  The court specifically found, as to the factor of beneficial results received by each party, that, due to the unreasonable nature of Husbandâ€™s settlement demands, it was Wife who obtained the most beneficial result of the litigation.Â  Furthermore, the family court found many of the remaining factors favored an award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  Because there is certainly evidence in the record supporting the conclusions of the family court regarding attorneyâ€™s fees, we find no abuse of discretion in the award. See Henggeler v. Hanson, 333 S.C. 598, 605, 510 S.E.2d 722, 726 (Ct. App. 1998)Â  (finding no abuse of discretion in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees when the family court considered the necessary factors and there was evidence supporting the courtâ€™s conclusions).
For the foregoing reasons, the family courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The Home was awarded Wife in a prior divorce decree.Â  When Wifeâ€™s first husband ceased making court-ordered mortgage payments, Wife used borrowed money to rescue the Home from foreclosure proceedings.
[3] The family court order refers to Wifeâ€™s additional twenty-five percent interest in this marital asset as a â€œspecial equityâ€ in the property.Â  Generally, the term â€œspecial equityâ€ is used to describe the special interest a spouse gains in nonmarital property by contributing to an increase in the propertyâ€™s value over the course of a marriage.Â  See, e.g., Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 106, 529 S.E.2d 14, 20 (2000); Arnal v. Arnal, 363 S.C. 268, 294, 609 S.E.2d 821, 835 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The term is not widely used to describe a spouseâ€™s interest in marital property.Â  This semantic oddity, however, is not raised by Husband on appeal; thus, we will not discuss it further.

PER CURIAM: This appeal arises from the removal hearing and the termination of parental rights (TPR) of Sabrina Nedrow.Â  The court found her parental rights should be terminated on six grounds:Â  1) the child or another child in the home has been harmed, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months; 2) the parent has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal; 3) a willful failure to visit; 4) a willful failure to provide support; 5) the parent has a diagnosable condition unlikely to change within a reasonable time; and 6) the child has been in DSSâ€™ custody for 15 of 22 months.Â  Additionally, the court found termination was in the best interest of the child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2004).
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), we affirm[1] the family courtâ€™s ruling and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
AFFIRMED.
